exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art
exhibition_title: First Fire: Richard Bresnahan and New Pottery from St. John's
exhibition_description: This exhibition featured potter Richard Bresnahan and the remarkable results obtained from the first firing of a new wood-burning kiln on the campus of St. John's University, St. Cloud, Minnesota. Bresnahan, who apprenticed with the Japanese Nakazato family of potters, well known for his skillfully thrown, uniquely-glazed ceramics and for his commitment to the environment -- used materials indigenous to Minnesota and stoked his kiln with waste wood gathered from the forests surrounding St. John's. The successful firing of the enormous 1,200 cubic feet, three-chamber kiln marked a high point in Bresnahan's artistic career. In addition to the subtle hues of natural ash glazes, the final chamber of the kiln also yielded unglazed ceramics with flash marks of bright reds and oranges, and contrasting soft tans and browns. This exhibition included 50-60 of these objects, and included large-scale storage jars, vases, platters, and teabowls.

exhibition_title: The Twin Cities on Paper: A Century of Architectural Drawings for Minneapolis and Saint Paul
exhibition_description:
Organized by The Minneapolis Institute of Arts in honor of the American Institute of Architects’ annual meeting in Minneapolis in May, this exhibition looked at local buildings from the perspective of their drawings and models. Dating from 1880s to the 1900s, these works were arranged typologically, beginning with museum, followed by other buildings in the public realm such as churches, hotels, libraries, and office buildings and concluding with domestic architecture for both town and country. 
The majority of the drawings came from the impressive holdings of the Northwest Architectural Archives, University of Minnesota Libraries, St. Paul; in addition, Avery Library, Columbia University, New York, and the Heinz Architectural Center at The Carnegie Museum of Art, Pittsburgh, lent less familiar works which created a more comprehensive architectural representation of the Twin Cities.
Architect highlighted in the exhibition included Edwin Lundie, well known locally for his residential architecture of the 1920s and 1930s; Harvey Ellis, gifted draughtsman for LeRoy Buffington around 1890 and who later designed furniture for Gustav Stickley; William Channing Whitney, designer of homes for many prominent Minnesotans at the turn of the century, and John Howe, a highly talented draughtsman for Frank Lloyd Wright.

exhibition_title: Reginald Sanders, March 6 - April 20, 1997
exhibition_description: An exhibition of kinesthetic abstraction and miniature collage work by 75 year old artist, writer, and musician, Reginald Sanders, explored the relationship between jazz and contemporary abstraction.

Household Names: The Rise of the Industrial Designer
American Sublime: Epic Landscapes of our Nation 1820-1880
exhibition_description: The focus of the exhibition are the great American landscape painters of the mid-19th century, concentrating on the Hudson River School and their contemporaries, who first gave complete visual expression to the idea of America as a vast new world. They took to a logical conclusion many of the ideas about landscape that had preoccupied European artists in the 18th and 19th centuries, while retaining the special character of the country they were exploring: magnificent, dramatic and subtle, by turns. The exhibition will include approximately 80 oil paintings featuring works by Bierstadt, Church, Cole, and Cropsey, among others.

From Where My Parents Came: Portraits from the Ukraine
exhibition_description: An exhibition of portraits by photographer Katherine Turczan explored the contemporary lives of women in the Ukraine, and examined the extraordinary changes of the post-Communist era.

exhibition_title: Lives Connected: Jacob Lawrence and Gwendolyn Knight, including “The Frederick Douglass and Harriet Tubman Series of Narrative Paintings by Jacob Lawrence”
exhibition_description: The artists Jacob Lawrence and Gwendolyn Knight met while working in Harlem in the 1930s; their friendship led to marriage in 1941, and their long relationship has been a vital factor in both artist’s work. Jacob Lawrence’s series on Frederick Douglass and Harriet Tubman of 1938-40 told the story of these African-American heroes in over 60 sequential panels. While Jacob’s paintings told a story and relate to his cultural history, Gwendolyn’s paintings and prints were more personal and represent the people and experiences which have filled her life.

exhibition_title: Gods and Goblins: Japanese Folk Paintings from Otsu
Three Centuries of Tradition: The Renaissance of Custom Sporting Arms in America
exhibition_description: Three Centuries of Tradition featured examples of work by living American gunmakers known for their translations of traditional European, British, and American sporting arms of various styles made between 1640 and 1940. An introductory section featured sporting arms made during that timeframe which served as stylistic and technological guides for contemporary work. Three Centuries of Tradition presented custom-made sporting arms as consummate examples of the decorative arts, demonstrating the highest artistic achievements in carving, inlay, and engraving of metal and wood. Guest curators for the exhibition include gunsmith Mark Silver, and Wallace Gusler, Master Gunsmith at Colonial Williamsburg. A catalogue accompanied the exhibition.

exhibition_title: John Twachtman: An American Impressionist
The Allure of the Maine Coast: Robert Henri and His Circle,1903-18
Quality Control
exhibition_description: An exhibition of paintings, prints, mixed media and installation work by Ruthann Godollei, Alexa Horochowski, Lee Anne Swanson and Carolyn Swiszcz, four artists known for material innovation and narrative irony. Ruthann Godollei decoded patterns of family and social dysfunction in sparse, scratchboard drawings and monoprints depicting text and simple domestic objects. Alexa Horochowski scrutinized that behemoth institution known as marriage in a multi-sensory laundry room equipped with bubbles, a working ringer washer, and clothes line installed with embroidered underwear. Lee Anne Swanson combined hi-tech materials and lo-tech ideas in an installation that accessorized a huge, moody painting with a line of waist-high livestock tanks containing splashing glitter-covered mechanical duck decoys. Carolyn Swiszcz revealed her love for accidental gesture and material flexibility in a giant eraser board mandala.

exhibition_title: Arnold Newman Portraits
exhibition_description: Arnold Newman is one of the best-known and most distinguished portrait photographers of the 20th century. He pioneered “environmental portraiture,” a style that places the subject in a carefully composed setting that captures the essence of their work and personality. Since the 1930s, Newman has used his impeccable technique and innovative strategies to photograph many of the most accomplished people of the century – artists, writers, actors, composers, politicians and others – for publications such as Life, Holiday, Fortune and The New Yorker.

exhibition_title: The Metamorphosis to Freedom
Reading and Collecting Books 1995-1996
John Howe in Minnesota: The Prairie School Legacy of Frank Lloyd Wright
exhibition_description: John (Jack) Howe was Frank Lloyd Wright’s talented chief draftsman from 1935 until Wright’s death in 1959. One of the first members of Wright’s Taliesin Fellowship, which was begun in 1932, Howe was schooled in the principles of organic architecture. In Wright’s studio, he directed the activities of the drafting room and completed many of Wright’s presentation drawings. Howe moved to Minnesota in the mid-1960s, where he ran his own architectural practice that focused, like Wright’s, on domestic architecture. This exhibition was comprised of 75 to 100 drawings mainly from the collections of the Northwest Architectural Archives, and the University Libraries, University of Minnesota. The exhibition coincides with the Frank Lloyd Wright Conservancy’s Annual Meeting, to be held September 20 – 24, 2000 in Minneapolis.

exhibition_title: Hair Stories
exhibition_description: This exhibition and event series presented the work of four visual artists, three writers, and one art historian to explore the personal, cultural, and mythological significance of hair. “Hair Stories” featured visual and verbal texts dealing with body-related issues: mixed media work by Diane Katsiaficas, paintings by Nancy Robinson, mixed media work and handmade paper by Erica Spitzer Rasmussen, and a video installation by Mara Zoltners; text and readings by Paulette Alden Bates, Valerie Miner, and Mary François Rockcastle; and a curated presentation of hair weavings from private Minnesota collections by Michael Stoughton, who will also contribute an essay on the historical use of hair in art and ornament. And because everyone has personal associations with hair, the gallery design provided opportunities for museum visitors to contribute to a collaborative work.

exhibition_title: Maxfield Parrish: 1870-1966
American Impressionism: Treasures from the Smithsonian American Art Museum
Toys for Tea
An Acre of Art
exhibition_description: An Acre of Art reflected the focused engagement of artists Mark Knierim and Robert Lawrence with one acre of rural land which they will visit, research and experience for one year. Their process/performance culminated in an exhibition held in three locations: MAEP’s gallery at The Minneapolis Institute of Arts; the World Wide Web; and on the land itself. An Acre of Art extended the work of Knierim and Lawrence, both of whom are known for sculpture and site specific installations that deal with the cultural and physical aspects of place.

Master Drawings from the Collection of Alfred Moir
exhibition_description: Alfred Moir, a retired art history professor and native Minnesotan, assembled an impressive private collection of mainly old master Italian drawings. There were also several French, Dutch and Spanish works and 19th-century drawings. His research over the years has yielded new attributions and expands our knowledge of artists working in the 16th, 17th, and 18th centuries. The exhibition was comprised of 75 drawings that included: black and colored chalks; pen and ink; brush and ink work and watercolor.

exhibition_title: Night
exhibition_description: This exhibition featured nightscapes by photographer Chris Faust and painter Mike Lynch, artists who for many years have produced work that reveals the essence of the urban landscape. Diligent explorers of the physical worlds they are both drawn to places that seem to stretch over time – empty dock yards, railroad yards, industrial sites, architectural landmarks, and myriad nighttime haunts. Chris Faust is well known for panoramic black-and-white photographs of landscape, images often filled with contradiction and the enduring tension between humans and nature. A disciplined and masterly technician, Faust achieves lush tonal quality through a process called compensation development, which hear leaned from John Sexton, a student of Ansel Adams. Mike Lynch has been recognized for decades as an artist whose oil paintings, watercolors, and drawings display rare economy and sensitivity. He has devoted himself to night scenes since 1953, when he began painting in earnest. Lynch creates his evocative work through the use of time-honored practices such as nineteenth-century British watercolor techniques.

Made in U.S.A., l'art americain, 1908-1943, entre nationalisme et internationalisme
On Sacred Terrain
exhibition_description: On Sacred Terrain is a photo essay on the people and history of the Holy Land by Minneapolis based photographer, Stuart D. Klipper.  The selected photos represent the theme of three great world religions, Judaism, Christianity, and Islam, which have focused on this land as a sacred center.

exhibition_title: Body Work: Photographs of Nudes
exhibition_description: This exhibition, drawn primarily from the Institute’s permanent collection, featured the work of about ten internationally known photographers. Their pictures spanned over one hundred years and represented every major movement in photography. Eadweard Muybridge, working in the late 19th-century, included nude men and women extensive analysis of human motion. Edward Steichen, as a turn-of-the-century pictorialist, idealized the nude, making evocative, soft-focus images. And Edward Weston, working after World War I, created modernist images of women, often emphasizing abstract shapes and forms. During the second half of the 20th-century, photographers such as Bill Brandt and July Coleman, continued to engage the human figure in a wide range of imagery, making it one of the medium’s most enduring subjects.

exhibition_department: Art of Africa and the Americas
exhibition_title: Staffs of Life: Rods, Staffs, Scepters, and Wands from the Coudron Collection of African Art
exhibition_description: This exhibition was composed of staffs, scepters, and other prestigious objects from West and Central Africa, drawn from a highly significant private collection. Although linked by their unusual form, the objects in the exhibition showed an astonishing variety of sculptural form and decoration, ranging from studies of the human figure to extreme abstraction. The exhibition was accompanied by a catalogue of the entire collection.

exhibition_title: Kitchen: Liza Lou
exhibition_description: "Kitchen" was a 150 square foot beaded environment of incredible detail. A grocery list hung from the refrigerator door, blue beads flowed from the sink spigot over a pile of dishes and a beaded cherry pie sat in the oven. The installation centered on the role of women in history and their labor-intensive work in the room where so many women have spent decades of their lives. The artist glorified the drudgery of domestic work and in so doing created a space for critical reflection about the role of women in the home and what is traditionally seen as "women's work."

exhibition_title: Degas and America: The Early Collectors
exhibition_description: This exhibition examined the early response to Degas in America and was the first to investigate this under-explored chapter in Degas’ critical fortunes. It included about 75 works in all media that were either exhibited or acquired in America toward the end of the 19th century or in the early part of the 20th century. A catalogue accompanied the exhibition.

exhibition_title: Poetic Horizons: The Landscape Tradition in Britain, 1750-1850
exhibition_description:
The century between 1750 and 1850 , often referred to as the "golden age" of British landscape art, when the genre reached perhaps its highest level of achievement and recognition. This exhibition was designed to survey the work of the leading British landscape artists of the period, with a special emphasis on watercolors and prints. The exhibition featured more than 180 prints, drawings, watercolors and paintings drawn from the Institute's permanent collection and other institutional and private collections. A selection of prints and preparatory drawings from Turner's landmark publication Liber Studiorum, was highlighted. A technical display and a selection of English decorative arts was also shown.
An illustrated catalogue was produced by The Minneapolis Institute of Arts.

exhibition_title: George Earl Resler: Minnesota Etcher
exhibition_description: This exhibition presented a retrospective of the work of St. Paul artist George Resler (1882-1954). It included a selection of etchings, drypoints, and drawings of Resler's preferred subject of landscape as well as portraits of family and friends. Many of his landscapes featured Minnesota scenes and St. Paul in particular. Resler was inspired by the painter-etchers of the 19th century such as James McNeill Whistler, Seymour Haden and Alphonse Legros. This exhibition reintroduced the artist to the general public and marks the first time the Institute exhibited the works of George Resler. A publication accompanied the exhibition.

exhibition_title: The Color Red: Messages in Textile Art
The Poetics of Vision: Photographs from the Collection of Harry M. Drake
exhibition_description: This exhibition highlighted the strengths of Harry Drake's collection of about 250 photographs. Fully half of the images are by Minor White, representing the most significant private collection of this important artist's work. The exhibition examined Harry's personal eye as a collector and the varied artistry of the major twentieth-century photographers whose work he has acquired. Seventy-five photographs by 25 photographers were included in the exhibition some of whom were Minor White, Paul Caponigro, Wynn Bullock, Brett Weston, Michael Kenna, David Teplica, Eikoh Hosoe and Josef Sudek. A catalogue accompanied the exhibition.

exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art
exhibition_title: Otsu-e: Japanese Folk Paintings from the Harriet & Edson Spencer Collection
riverheart
exhibition_description: This installation featured photographer/installation artist Linda Rossi who combined illuminated sculpture, video, sound, and still photography in a "room of the seasons." Rossi used images of the environment (still work and footage from Minnesota and Africa) and the human body in multi-referential narratives that explored personal, cultural, and geographic territories.

exhibition_title: Henri Cartier-Bresson: Pen, Brush, and Cameras
exhibition_description: This was a major retrospective exhibition that explored the career of Henri Cartier-Bresson, one of the leading photo-journalists of twentieth-century photography. The exhibition was comprised of nearly 100 drawings and photographs selected by the artist, included for the first time a representative sampling of eight rarely exhibition oil paintings and seven films by or about the artist. The exhibition toured selected museum during 1996 and 1997. A small illustrated catalogue accompanied the exhibition and included an essay by a leading Cartier-Bresson scholar.

exhibition_title: Jean Puiforcat's Coffee and Tea Service and the Art Deco Style
exhibition_description: This exhibition focused on a recent acquisition of The Minneapolis Institute of Arts, a rare and important silver Art Deco coffee and tea service by French silversmith Jean Puiforcat. The exhibition discussed the service in the context of the work of Jean Puiforcat and the Art Deco style in Europe and America.

exhibition_title: Henri Matisse: La revelation m'est venue de l'Orient

exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art
exhibition_title: Netsuke: The Japanese Art of Miniature Carving
exhibition_description: As demand for large scale Buddhist sculpture declined in seventeenth century Japan, the secular form of miniature sculpture, called netsuke, rose to prominence. Netsuke were an integral part of Japanese dress during the Edo period (1600-1868) and characterized the era's concepts of iki, a chic sense of stylishness and shadatsu, a sensible sort of Bohemianism. This exhibition explored the beginnings of netsuke production, major schools of netsuke carving, contemporary netsuke artists and major iconographic themes.

exhibition_title: Photography: The Collection Grows, 1983 - 1996
Objects of Desire: The Modern Still Life

venues.venue: Museum of Modern Art, New York

exhibition_title: New England Hearth and Home | A Passion for the Past: The Collection of Bertram K. and Nina Fletcher Little at Cogswell's Grant, and Inherited and Collected: The Arts of New England in Minnesota
exhibition_description: These complementary exhibitions explored Minnesota’s New England roots. “A Passion for the Past” showcased a remarkable collection of folk and fine art, including paintings, drawings, furniture, textiles, and ceramics. “Inherited and Collected” featured objects brought to Minnesota by early settlers and items collected today by Twin Citians.

exhibition_title: Color, Color, Who's Got the Color? Kaffe Fassett
exhibition_description: Highlighted in the exhibition were 136 works of the textile artist and colorist, Kaffe Fassett. The exhibition was based on a retrospective held at the Victoria and Albert Museum, London. Included were works ranging from the first piece knitted by the artist to needlepoint carpets, site installations and wall hangings. The intricate patterns and lush colors of his knitted and needlework pieces illustrated Mr. Fassett’s use of nature and decorative objects for his design inspiration.

exhibition_title: Starburst Splendor: Selections from the Minnesota Quilt Project
exhibition_description: The quilts included in this exhibition were drawn from the Minnesota Quilt Project, an organization that was founded in 1988 to document historic quilts and quilt makers in Minnesota. The quilts in the exhibition featured the star motif, a design theme that includes many popular patterns and one that was particularly favored by Native American quilt makers. All quilts were made in America, but were not limited to those made in Minnesota. The length of the exhibition incorporated two rotations of twenty quilts each.

exhibition_title: Art and Archaeology of Ancient West Mexico
Relative Perfection
exhibition_description: An exhibition of new installations by Leigh Kane, Cynthia Morgan, and Barbra Nei shook up the formulaic world of conventional culture. These feminist works tempered a host of serious questions about contemporary expression, shedding light on the complexity of presentation and cultural documentation.

exhibition_title: Mantras: Paintings of Repetition
exhibition_description: This exhibition featured large-scale “romantic minimalist” paintings by German-born artist Barbara Kreft, who has made the Upper Midwest her home for nearly two decades. This region’s diverse landscape - its wide horizons and high arctic sky - has profoundly influenced her work. Well known for her elegantly evocative paintings of magical plant-filled environments, Kreft had depicted mysterious light-filled spaces containing pods, seeds, and various floating organic forms that seem to reflect psychological states of being. Her recent paintings speak to the luminous beauty of the earth. They present natural phenomena and life pattern in simpler spaces that suggest constellations of various sorts. The atmospheric and reductive quality of these large canvases heightened their contemplative effect and encouraged the viewer to linger in the artist’s ethereal landscape.

exhibition_title: Robert Delaunay, from Impressionism to Abstract Art
Memory of the Hand: Making Sense of Art through Touch
exhibition_description: Featured in this exhibition were the works of Rosalyn Driscoll, who has created sculpture for those with limited or no vision. Two to three of her sculptures, in addition to selections from The Minneapolis Institute of Arts’ permanent collection, were displayed to encourage museum audiences to think about the knowledge gained about art through the sense of touch.

exhibition_title: Morrison's Horizons
exhibition_description: The unique and abiding vision of critically acclaimed modernist, George Morrison, is honored in his 80th year through this special exhibition of recent paintings that extend his famous “Horizon Series.” George Morrison (b. 1919) was the first and most prominent Native American artist on the New York art scene in the 1940s. For five decades he has been recognized for a prolific career as an abstract painter and sculptor and is represented in museum, private, and corporate collections regionally, nationally, and internationally. Morrison is seen as a prominent figure of the American Indian Fine Arts Movement.

exhibition_title: Holiday Traditions in the Period Rooms
100 Years of Gund Toys
exhibition_description: A small exhibition of Gund toys held in conjunction with the “Bear House” benefit sponsored by the Friends of the Institute.

exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art
exhibition_title: Ancient Gold: Jewelry from the Dallas Museum of Art
exhibition_description: The Dallas Museum of Art’s collection of Mediterranean gold represents a historically wide-ranging group of ancient work from the critical periods of Greek and Etruscan jewelry making and is one of the finest such collections in the United States. 105 objects ranging from exotic Etruscan fibula and earrings to a Greek olive wreath and medallions and a representation of Roman gold work, including a dramatic snake armlet, were featured. The selection allows the viewer to understand the stylistic development during the 1,000 year period from the 7th-century BC to the 3rd-century AD and the importance of gold and the display of wealth was to these three cultures.

A World of Art: Gifts for the New Millennium
exhibition_description: This exhibition included approximately 200 important gifts to the museum given by individuals and corporations or purchased by our curators over the past ten years. Each curatorial department was represented. The arrival of more than 60 contemporary works of art from Target’s corporate art collection, nearly 4,000 textiles from the Jack Lenor Larsen archive donated by Cowtan & Tout in 1999, 475 objects from the Norwest Modernism Collection donated by Wells Fargo in 1998, and the ongoing gifts of Asian art from Ruth and Bruce Dayton all contributed to this opportunity to view an encyclopedic collection of world art. This collection embodied remarkable depth and breadth, providing a solid launching point and establishing a high level of quality for the museum’s future.

exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art
exhibition_title: A Japanese Legacy: Four Generations of Yoshida Family Artists
exhibition_description: This exhibition features oil paintings, watercolors and woodblock prints by nine artists from a single Japanese family spanning, four generations and over 100 years. The exhibition addresses the evolution of the popular Japanese print from the late 1800s to present; the adaptation of western styles—naturalism and abstraction—into Japanese styles, methods and aesthetics; and, the dynamics of the family tradition in its commercial, stylistic, and interpersonal dimensions. The Yoshida family is fascinating because of the longevity and breadth of the family’s artistic legacy, its high aesthetic standards, and its internationalism. Thus, this exhibition allows for multiple foci, including aesthetics, production, culture, politics, and personalities.

A Studio of Her Own: Boston Women Artists 1870-1940
Claude Monet and Frederic Bazille: Early Impressionism and Collaboration in the Studio
Masters of American Photography
Michael Mazur: A Print Retrospective
exhibition_description: This retrospective exhibition highlighted the graphic art produced by Michael Mazur between 1958 and 1998. It provided an overview of the themes Mazur has explored over the years and reveals the depth of his talent as a graphic artist.

exhibition_title: Present/On the Road to Bazzano
exhibition_description: This exhibition featured two groups of large-scale works by one of America’s leading contemporary photographers. The culmination of a six-year project photographing the olive orchards and sacred trees of Spoleto, Italy, it revealed JoAnn Verburg’s profound interest in the reciprocity between humans and nature. The exhibition addressed the interrelatedness of life cycles, agriculture, and commerce and the mystery of sacred landscape. The installation reflected a sensitivity to architecture, human scale, and implied and actual time— issues more often addressed by installation art, architecture, or theater than by conventional photography. Verburg saw the olive tree, a life form essential to Italian culture, as a powerful metaphor for exchange. She made a gift of these works in her presentation of living cultural icons that do much to stimulate our own wonder and our own relationships with place and with what is sacred in nature.

exhibition_title: Howard Ben Tré: Sculpting Space in the Public Realm
exhibition_description: This exhibition focused on the glass sculptor Howard Ben Tré’s public projects for plazas and streetscapes, which are an increasingly important part of his work. A major component of the exhibition was the project recently approved by Target Corporation for their new public plaza in downtown Minneapolis. Howard Ben Tré is a very important player in the studio glass movement that developed in the 1960s and 1970s in Providence, Rhode Island. He has produced sculptures in cast translucent glass, employing an industrial process and medium known to him from working in various trades as a young man. His pieces exhibited extreme control and symmetry, and resembled ancient archeological finds. The sculptures developed as freestanding works that combine totemic forms with light (transmitted and reflected) and water to create a transcendent experience that invites human interaction.

exhibition_title: Ceramics as Sculpture: Challenging the Functional Tradition
Exquisite Moments: West Lake and Southern Song Art
Streamline: The Dawn of Tomorrow
Goya, un regard libre

exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art
exhibition_title: Suzuki Harunobu
Letter Perfect: The Art of Modernist Typography, 1896-1953
exhibition_description: This exhibition documented an important episode of typographic design through the collection of The Minneapolis Institute of Arts. It traced the progression of innovative letterforms from the turn of the 20th century to the 1950s, roughly a sixty-year period in which typography reflected the tremendous upheaval generated by the avant-garde in all the arts. Those advances made in a series of modernist movements, from Arts and Crafts, Art Nouveau, Dadaism, De Stijl, and Russian Constructivism through the Bauhaus, were graphically captured.

exhibition_title: Views of the Mississippi
Painted Prints: Renaissance and Baroque Hand-Colored Engravings, Etchings, and Woodcuts

exhibition_department: Art of Africa and the Americas
exhibition_title: Jewels of the Southwest: The Development of Contemporary Design in Southwest American Indian Jewelry

venues.venue: Museum of Indian Arts and Culture

exhibition_title: Blown Out of Proportion: A Survey of Studio Glass
exhibition_description: The first display of glass in the Institute’s Contemporary Ceramics and Glass Gallery, this installation featured 10-15 works of studio glass, beginning with examples by pioneering personalities in the movement from the 1950s-1970s, and following through with the work of contemporary designers. These American and international glass objects were drawn from the Institute as well as from local collections.

exhibition_title: Pierre Bonnard: Early and Late
Van Gogh and Gauguin: the 'Studio of the South'
American Gothic (Saturday Night/Sunday Morning) and Homo domesticus
exhibition_description: A double exhibition featuring a new film and sculpture by Chris Larson and an installation by drawing-based artist Melissa Stang. Known for his giant wooden machines “that work in the minds of the viewer,” Chris Larson presented his second film project that uses his sculpture as a theatrical set. As creative director, actor, set designer, and builder, Larsen used poetic themes of Americana and vaudeville to extend his inquiry into metamorphosis, the sacred and profane, or what country western music calls, “Saturday Night/Sunday Morning. In her exhibit, Homo domesticus, Melissa Stang presented two new works. One, a monumental assembled painting that sought to reconcile the expectations she feels as a woman artist; the other, a domestic interior of a mysterious herpetologist filled with kitschy decorative art objects depicting reptiles and amphibians. A table set with three-legged frog patterned plates (all drawn by Stang) reminded us to heed nature’s warnings and pays homage to the humble creatures who have given their lives for “human progress.”

exhibition_title: The Industrial Design Aesthetic 1900-1950
exhibition_description: This exhibition brings together a selection of industrial designs dating roughly from 1900 to 1950 (all the result of collaborative efforts, in some instances the individual designer’s identity remains unknown). The selection is purposely devoted to “industrial strength” designs that challenge long-standing concepts of beauty and taste. These designers and manufacturers were attempting to free themselves of applied decoration – function being the driving force. Such advanced ideas as engineering, utility, aerodynamics, styling, streamlining and the exploration of new techniques and materials were shared concerns.

exhibition_title: L'Ecole de Barbizon
Cultural Crosscurrents: Elizabeth Catlett and Francisco Mora
The Triumph of French Paintings: Seventeenth Century Masterpieces from the Museums of FRAME

exhibition_title: Sesson in the World of Ink Painting: A Super Eccentric of Japan's Warring States Period
Wood Turning in North American Since 1930
"Turning" Over Time: Historic Seating Furniture
exhibition_description: To put “Wood Turning in North America Since 1930” in historical context, this exhibition displayed examples of seating furniture from the museum’s permanent collection and private collections.

exhibition_title: Lipchitz and the Avant-Garde: From Paris to New York

venues.venue: Board of Trustees of the University of Illinois, Krannert Art Museum

exhibition_title: Elegy: A Tribute Performance by the Twin Cities Arts Community
Frontera Lake Street
exhibition_description: "Frontera Lake Street" was presented through the museum's artist-run curatorial department, the Minnesota Artists Exhibition Program (MAEP), and by "Grupo Soap del Corazon ("spanglish" for "soap of the heart"), a group of artists and cultural activists devoted to the promotion of "border" culture in Minnesota. Grupo Soap produces and presents an ongoing series of exhibitions and projects that acknowledge, in particular, the Latinization of Lake Street in Minneapolis, with its mercados, taquerias, tortillerias, Latin record stores, nightclubs, boot shops, and salons. The Frontera Six borrowed from Mexican popular culture, each assumed the persona of an imaginary professional wrestler. In creating their own pop-wrestler characters, each Frontera artist invented a distinct personality and stage name, complete with masks and costumes. These theatrical characters worked to advertise the exhibition as well as to reconcile and celebrate "high" and "low" art. The artwork featured in the gallery installation included tiny landscapes painted on corn, rice, and other seeds by Salvador Espejo Benitez, depicted scenes of Minnesota on one side, and of Mexico, on the other. Luis Fitch's mixed-media work illustrated the opportunities that have drawn Mexicans to Minnesota as well as the risks that they have taken to cross over. A Central American-style trinket cart by Alexa Horochowski was packed with saleable art miniatures including hand-painted surrogate wrestling figures of the Frontera artists themselves. Douglas Padilla's intense symbolist paintings referenced the North and the South, connecting the Mississippi with the desert. Chilean painter Marcela Rodriguez A. was inspired by her Latino students and the landscape of her homeland. Xavier Tavera's large-scale color photographs revealed Latinos as both visible and invisible.

exhibition_title: Antiques Show and Sale 2001
Danny Lyon: Photographs 1962-2000
exhibition_description: This was the first exhibition at The Minneapolis Institute of Arts of this internationally important documentary photographer whose work became part of the permanent collection in 1986. In April, 2001 two portfolios featuring Lyon’s images from the Civil Rights Movement (1962 – 1964) and his 1965 project “Uptown” were added to the Institute’s permanent collection.

exhibition_title: L'esprit créateur de Pigalle à Canova: Terres cuites européennes de 1750 à 1830
The Engravings of Lucas van Leyden
Picasso: Prints in the 20th Century
exhibition_description: This exhibition brings together a selection of approximately 75 prints that trace the development of Pablo Picasso's printmaking activities from 1904 until 1970. The exhibition includes etchings, drypoints, lithographs, and color linoleum cuts that reflect nearly every aspect of this prolific artist's extraordinary career.

exhibition_title: Holiday Traditions in the Period Rooms

exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art
exhibition_title: Beyond Ukiyo-e: Modern Japanese Landscape Prints
In Situ
exhibition_description: The Minnesota Artists Exhibition Program (MAEP) presented "In Situ", which featured new paintings by contemporary artists Jil Evans, James Holmberg, and Cristi Rinklin, three artists engaged with the creative connections between their paintings and the spaces that they occupy. Named for the Latin phrase, in situ, which means, roughly, "in the original location," the exhibition presented Evan's pseudo-figurative works, suspended overhead, to suggest the ceiling of a Baroque interior; Holmberg' s large-scale minimalist canvases, accompanied by painted "details" of the larger works; and Rinklin' s lush, wonder-filled oval paintings, "framed" with paint placed directly onto the gallery wall. Through their collaborative planning and process, the In Situ" artists established the exhibit's site-specific considerations, including what paintings to execute, object placement, color and lighting, and gallery design. Their installation offered a progression of experiences designed to heighten perceptual awareness for the viewer, illuminating the relationship between abstraction and observation.

exhibition_title: Jack Lenor Larsen: The Company and the Cloth
exhibition_description: Using Jack Lenor Larsen fabrics, the exhibition looked at high-end textile manufacturing in the last half of the 20th-century, emphasizing its international character and close association to contemporary aesthetic preferences of western culture. The focus centered on creative design and production, bringing attention to a variety of issues which affected the end product, including cottage production to high tech manufacturing, the availability of materials, tariff restrictions, trade wars, among others. The Jack Lenor Larsen archive was formally given to the museum and the University of Minnesota in 1999.

exhibition_title: Amedeo Modigliani
Conversation Pieces: The Modern Telephone 1930-2000
Recent Accessions
exhibition_description: This exhibition featured a selection of some of the MIA’s most notable recent acquisitions.

exhibition_title: Larry Rivers: Art and the Artist
Functionalism to Funk: California Ceramics
exhibition_description: This installation presents the work of ceramic artists in California from the 1940s, when renowned potters Beatrice Wood and Marguerite Wildenhain set up their wheels to make striking incised and glazed pots, through the present. “Functionalism to Funk” also tells the story of the irreverent “Funk” movement in ceramics that began in the 1960s with Robert Arneson’s comical portrait busts. The installation features several new ceramic sculptures in the Institute’s collection, including a monumental stack pot by Peter Voulkos and a bust by Arneson of Viola Frey (whose work is also represented in the exhibition).

exhibition_title: The Chair: Sculptural Form in Wood 1880-1960

exhibition_department: Art of Africa and the Americas
exhibition_title: Sacred Symbols: Four Thousand Years of Ancient American Art
exhibition_description:
The Sacred Symbols exhibition provided a unique opportunity to see the arts created by the people of the ancient Americas in all their beauty, variety and complexity. It featured works from a selection of the notable civilizations found throughout North, Central and South America, objects ranging in time of creation from 2500 BC to the initial period of contact with Europeans in the 16th century. These pieces represented a great variety of artistic styles powerfully expressing the fundamental religious, historical and political aspects of the lives of the people who created them. 
All of the approximately 180 objects in the exhibition were selected from the collections of American museums in the FRAME (French Regional American Museums Exchange) consortium and are masterpieces reflecting the strongest works available throughout the United States. Highlights of the show included elegant ceramics decorated with abstract and representational art designs from the Southwestern region of the present United States, as well as refined stone sculptures, ceramics and personal ornaments from the Southeast. Ancient Mexican cultures were represented by the superbly carved jade statues of figures and animals of the Olmec, the expertly painted ceramic vessels illustrating themes from mythology and history, and elaborately carved stone figures created by artists of the Maya civilization, and the inventive ceramic sculptures from the people of the Colima, Nayarit and Jalisco regions representing different aspects of everyday life. From Central America there were magnificent golden ornaments fashioned in the form of human beings, mythological figures and animals, which were used by chiefs and other people of high status to adorn themselves and mark their status. There were also beautifully modeled and painted ceramics from Ancient Peru, representing individuals, animals and objects from the ceremonial and political culture of the Moche and Nazca people, plus some highly ornamented Incan vessels that showed the interaction of Nat

exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art
exhibition_title: Japanese Dolls
Venere e Amore: Michelangelo e la nuova bellezza ideale
Emil Nolde im Dialog (1905-1913)
Vincent's Choice: the Musée Imaginaire of Van Gogh
Tzedakah
exhibition_description: The Jewish alms container known as the tzedekah box occupies a unique place among Jewish ritual objects. Whereas other religious objects are bound by their ritual purpose, the tzedekah box is unaffiliated. The word tzedekah is derived from the root “tzadek”, meaning justice or righteousness. Tzedekah is the Jewish commandment to provide for those that are less fortunate as a means of bringing justice to the world. Tzedekah boxes come in all shapes in sizes thereby offering unlimited opportunities for artists to interpret them. The project will send an invitation to local Jewish and non-Jewish artists, inviting them to create a tzedekah box. Approximately 30 winning designs will be displayed at community sites and culminate with an exhibition at The Minneapolis Institute of Arts. The Tzedekah Box Project will challenge viewers/participants to question their own place in society; their responsibilities to their community; and their ability to be social change agents. It will ask us to reflect on ways in which we could have been changed by philanthropy and ways in which our community may have been transformed by another’s generosity.

exhibition_title: High Touch
exhibition_description: Artists Laura Stack and Anne Sugnet come to the abundance of the natural world - to its ever-shifting patterns of replication - with great reverence. Both artists have experienced profound events with the physical body and consider making art to be a transcendent action. Through their work they seek to create an antidote to a high speed, high-tech world that operates beyond human pace. Their exhibition "High Touch", which features Stack's luminous black and white drawings and Sugnet's intimate mixed-media installations, offers a poetic investigation into the very essence of things. Here we find slow amassed time, things becoming and unbecoming, traces of touch, and tender constellations of forms. In both bodies of work, primordial forms emerge - forms that suggest seeds, cones, spirals, cells dividing, or the cosmos. These shapes are familiar and there is comfort in that re-cognition. Yet they are located in mysterious spaces and for that they do not feel didactic but more like déjà vu - that fleeting sense of knowing, shrouded in mystery. It seems that you've been here before - perhaps in another life, perhaps as a cell or a star.

exhibition_title: Coming of Age in Ancient Greece
Minton to Malibu: The Art of Glazed Tiles
exhibition_description: This exhibition traces the design history of ceramic tiles in America and Europe over the past three centuries, using examples from the Institute's own growing collection as well as those in private collections. The installation is organized in conjunction with the Tile Heritage Foundation’s annual meeting in the Twin Cities.

exhibition_title: Bridging America with Frank Lloyd Wright
exhibition_description: Bridging America with Frank Lloyd Wright celebrates the opening of the Marshall Field’s Bridge in Minneapolis, inspired by the work of Frank Lloyd Wright and designed by his successor firm, Taliesin Architects. The bridge, spanning Interstate 94 at Third Avenue South, forges a new connection between downtown Minneapolis, the Minneapolis Convention Center, and The Minneapolis Institute of Arts. To provide a context for the Marshall Field’s Bridge, the exhibition also examines over a dozen of Frank Lloyd Wright’s bridge projects through photo reproductions, models, and video. Produced over a sixty-year period, Wright’s designs range from simple footbridges in rural settings to multi-level, long-span urban bridges for both vehicles and pedestrians.

exhibition_title: Georgia O'Keeffe: From the Plains
Jim Dine Prints: 1985-2000
exhibition_description: This retrospective of Jim Dine’s prints will span the last fifteen years of the artist’s graphic oeuvre. It will feature approximately 100 lithographs, intaglios, woodcuts and illustrated books published by Pace Editions, Graphicstudio and the Arion Press, among others. A fully illustrated raisonné will accompany the exhibition. This exhibition is the fourth in a series of print retrospectives and catalogue raisonnés, preceded by Galerie Mikro, Berlin, 1970; Williams College Museum of Art, Williamstown, MA, 1977; and the Davison Art Center and the Ezra and Cecile Zilkha Gallery, Wesleyan University, Middletown, CT, 1986.

Immeasurable Spaces, Incalculable Engergies: Tobey, Graves, Anderson, Callahan
Judaica 2002 - 2003
Ruth Bernhard: Photographs 1930s-1970s
exhibition_description: The exhibition will feature 60 of Ruth Bernhard’s most significant photographs made over a period of more than 40 years. Beginning as a young commercial photographer in New York in 1927, Bernhard relocated to San Francisco in 1953, which has since been her base of activity. Her peers and associates have included all the major West Coast photographers of the 20th century – Edward Weston, Imogene Cunningham, Dorothea Lange, Minor White.

exhibition_title: Marcel Breuer in Minnesota
exhibition_description: Hungarian-born Marcel Breuer (1902-1981) developed his tubular steel cantilevered chair, one of his many innovative furniture designs, while at the Bauhaus design school in Germany in the 1920s. After immigrating to the United States in 1937, he practiced architecture with Walter Gropius for a decade before opening his own successful office. His buildings, including the Whitney Museum in New York and Unesco Headquarters in Paris, are as visually arresting as his furniture, and he is regarded as one of the most important modern architect/designers of the twentieth century. “Marcel Breuer in Minnesota” is organized by the Minneapolis Institute of Arts to mark the centenary of Breuer’s birth. This exhibition will feature his Minnesota projects, including the Abbey Church and campus at St. John’s University in Collegeville, and two house projects, as well as his furniture designs from the Institute’s collection.

exhibition_title: Holiday Traditions
Never Late for Heaven: The Art of Gwendolyn Knight
Naked! The Female Body and the Rise of Modernism

venues.venue: Städelsches Kunstinstitut und Städtische Galerie Frankfurt

exhibition_title: Hand Painted Pop: The Formative Years, 1955-1962
Constable to Delacroix: British Art and the French Romantics 1820-1840
Portrait: 3 Meters per Second
Light Bound: Photographers Regard the Book
exhibition_description: This exhibition includes the work of seven contemporary artists who have extensively photographed books. Working over the last ten years, as electronic publishing emerged, these photographers celebrated the traditional book, made of ink, paper, and glue. Their works show books as purveyors of popular culture, objects of physical beauty, vessels of information, and symbols of human knowledge. The exhibition consists of about 60 photographs and one installation by: Sally Alatalo, Peter Beard, James Henkel, Doug Keyes, Abelaredo Morell, Alison Rossiter, and JoAnn Verburg.

exhibition_title: R.P.M.
exhibition_description:
R.P.M. presents new work by Mollie Rabiner, J.J. Peet, and Don Myhre: interactive sculpture, fake (but possibly plausible) products and theatrical props “scented” with humor. Yet all three broker serious ideas that, due to their cultural (or counter-cultural) underpinnings, can seem cautionary, subversive or even sinister. 
Mollie Rabiner invites the gallery visitor to try their luck with relationships and candy-coated desires by playing her stage-set, coin operated, carnival claw and digger machine. J.J. Peet presents a curious array of fake objects designed to carry extreme value or that allude to some secret information or event. He questions the very nature of art through an assortment of found and handmade props -- bags of money; bricks of gold; a count-down-clock; and a mysterious brief case. Don Myhre presents a weird robotic amalgamation in his interactive sculpture, “Raft”. In it he combines a fiberglass jet ski, a downloaded landscape cast in foam, and a tattered taxidermied jackrabbit to create a whacked-out reference to the madness of American comodification.

exhibition_title: Three-Way Vision
exhibition_description: Three-Way Vision features new and recent bodies of work by artists Mary Carroll, Clea Felien, and Todd Severson who share notable technical mastery and who engage in what might be called a very obsessive aesthetic and process. The exhibition presents a wild assortment of work ranging from Carroll’s outrageously decorated ceramic vessels; to Felien’s familial portraits, drawn with her left hand and painted with her right; and Severson’s mammoth “collection” of chain saw portraits. “Three-Way Vision” reveals the complex assortment of issues that, for many artists living today, surround ideas about craft, facility, or documentation of culture.

exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art
exhibition_title: Eternal Egypt: Masterworks of Ancient Art from the British Museum
exhibition_description: Eternal Egypt: Masterworks of Ancient Art from the British Museum is the first major Egyptian exhibition to be drawn solely from the British Museum’s outstanding collection of Egyptian antiquities. Both renowned masterpieces and little-known treasures provide an overview of the richness and scope of this premiere collection of Egyptian art. The exhibition consists of 144 objects and spans the full range of pharaonic history, from shortly before the First Dynasty, about 3100 BC, to the Roman occupation of the fourth century AD. The four periods into which ancient Egyptian history is divided – the Old Kingdom, the Middle Kingdom, the New Kingdom, and the Late Period –form the underlying structure of the exhibition. A fully illustrated catalogue accompanies the exhibition. The catalogue is supported in part by Helen H. Scheidt.

exhibition_title: Courts of the Baroque Age: From Bernini and Velázquez to Luca Giordano
An Artist's Paradise: Minnesota Landscapes 1840-1940
Francis Bacon and the Tradition of Art
Eugène Delacroix, 1798-1863
Seurat and the Making of "La Grande Jatte"
Jasper Johns: Numbers
Grant Wood: Main Street
Crossing the Channel: British and French Painting in the Age of Romanticism
exhibition_description: This exhibition explored the relationship between French and British painting during the 1820s and 1830s when fascination with every level of Anglo-Scottish culture played a formative role in the development of modern French art. Approximately 120 paintings by 60 artists, including Turner, Bonington, Constable, Delacroix, Géricault, and Corot were on view. An exhibition catalogue accompanied the exhibition.

exhibition_title: Household Names: The Designer in American Life
exhibition_description: How have Americans become aware of who designs their everyday objects? With the advent of industrial production in the mid-19th century, household goods flooded European and American homes, but they were for the most part unattractive, owing to the little regard manufacturers gave toward their appearance. The 1930s introduced Americans to industrial designers such as Raymond Loewy, Henry Dreyfuss, and Walter Dorwin Teague, who became well known through their streamlined approach to everything from automobiles to thermostats, and through their books on the subject of design. By the 1940s, as consumers began to embrace modern design, manufacturers made a point of marketing goods under the “brand names”of their designers. Russel and Mary Wright and Charles and Ray Eames positioned themselves as practitioners of a new, casual lifestyle for which their modern products were perfectly suited. Today, with the faces and signatures of Philippe Starck and Michael Graves prominently featured on packaging, designers are often better known than their merchandise. Through objects from the Institute’s collection and from private collections, “Household Names”examines the designer’s rise to recognition in modern Ameerica.

exhibition_title: A New View: An Architect's Eye
Three Stories from Little America

exhibition_department: Art of Africa and the Americas
exhibition_title: Northern Visions: Art and Life of the Inuit
exhibition_description: This exhibition presented Inuit sculpture and prints lent by the Winnipeg Art Gallery, which has one of the world's largest and well-known collections of Inuit art, and featured objects from private collectors as well as the Institute's collection. Displaying mostly contemporary artwork from several Inuit communities located in northern Canada, "Northern Visions" explored significant themes in Inuit art such as animals, hunting, and origins and myths.

exhibition_title: Legacy of the Lathe: Gifts of Turned Wood from Robyn and John Hern and their Circle of Friends
Medardo Rosso

venues.venue: Galleria Civica d'Arte Moderna e Contemporanea di Torino
Museo di Arte Moderna e Contemporanea di Trento e Rovereto

Global Village: The 60s
Fréderic Bazille
Great Expectations: John Singer Sargent Painting Children
Max Beckmann

venues.venue: Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, New York

exhibition_title: Recent Acquisitions - February 2003 to April 2003
exhibition_description: This exhibition will feature a selection of some of the MIA’s most notable recent acquisitions.

exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art
exhibition_title: Seven Centuries of Chinese Painting: Recent Gifts from Joan Wurtele
exhibition_description: This exhibition featured more than thirty of the Chinese paintings acquired in recent years through the generosity of Joan Wurtele. The exhibit included small, lyrical landscapes and bird and flower paintings of the Southern Sung dynasty (1127–1279); delicate ink landscapes of the important early Ming (1368–1644); as well as work by Wu school artists, and some fine Buddhist paintings. Also included were representative professional and literati landscape paintings of the late Ming and Ch’ing dynasties (1644–1911), including works by Ku I-te (active 1608–33), Cha Shih-piao (1615–98), Kung Hsien (1619–89), and Lan Ying (1585-1664). Each of these paintings was selected with the museum’s collecting needs in mind. Care was taken to add significant scrolls that helped achieve our goal of building as representative and high quality a collection of Chinese paintings as possible.

exhibition_title: Grotto: an alternative reality by bill klaila
Modernist Kitchenware: The Counter Revolution, 1930-1960
exhibition_description:
Kitchenware?!! What comes to mind for many are pots and pans and potato peelers, perhaps. But, have you ever seen a Hollywood Liquefier, a toaster with a built-in conveyer belt, a “Coffee X” cold water extractor, a rotating “Twin-O-Matic” waffle iron, a “Top-O-Stove” potato baker, or our newest acquisition, a muscle-bound meat slicer, the pride of the pantry?
 
The third exhibition in the Institute’s “Case Studies in Design” series is devoted to modernist kitchenware. Ingenuity is often synonymous with modernity and such is the case with nearly forty works selected for this exhibition. Are you aware that one of the foremost designers represented in the exhibition, Harold Van Doren, served as Assistant Director of The Minneapolis Institute of Arts?
 
Comprised of kitchenware drawn from the Institute’s collection, complemented with additional loans, the works are inventive collaborations between designers, engineers, manufacturers and advertising agents resulting in some of the most remarkable utensils and appliances of the era. The one element missing is the aroma of freshly-brewed coffee, pancakes, maple syrup and crisp bacon. Nevertheless, it is an exhibition for all ages, homemakers or not.

exhibition_title: Declaration of Independence Road Trip
Apocalypse
exhibition_description: Albrecht Durer's Apocalypse stands as one the major achievements of pictorial art. His series of dramatic woodcuts are the production of his imaginative power and splendid draftsmanship, and introduces his new conception of the black and white print as an independent work of art. This exhibition presented the Institute's complete series of the 1511 edition.

exhibition_title: Governor's Residence: 2003-2012
Printmaking in the Age of Romanticism
exhibition_description: This exhibition highlighted a selection of lithographs, etchings, and mezzotints from the Institute ’s permanent collection that exemplify the tenets of Romanticism. The artists Eugène Delacroix, Théodore Géricault, Richard Parkes Bonnington, and J.M.W. Turner were active participants in this movement that valued imagination, emotion, exotic cultures, nature, and the literature of Byron, Scott, and Shakespeare. These and other related themes were explored in the works on display. The Romantic era stretched from the French Revolution in 1789 until the middle of the 19th century, with the most intense period of production beginning with the demise of Napoleon in 1815 and progressing until the early 1840s. While many of the artists represented in the exhibition are better known as painters, this exhibition revealed that they were also talented practitioners of lithography and etching. Featured prints included selections from Gericault’s English Set, J.M.W. Turner’s Liber Studiorum, and Bonnington’s views of Paris and Rouen, as well as Delacroix’s Royal Tiger.

exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art
exhibition_title: Shaped with a Passion: The Carl A. Weyerhaeuser Collection of Japanese Ceramics from the 1970s
exhibition_description: The exhibition featured 120 pieces of contemporary Japanese ceramics collected by Carl A. Weyerhauser in 1972 – 1973 and now housed in the Art Complex Museum, Duxbury, Massachusetts. In amassing the collection, every attempt was made to gather from different geographical areas in Japan, each representing a historic legacy of ceramic production. In addition to already recognized master potters — some designated Living National Treasures— remarkable works by emerging artists were also collected. The exhibition reflects the monolithic influence of the tea ceremony on Japanese ceramic production with the majority of the selected works, in form and technique, related to traditional tea wares.

exhibition_title: James Ensor
Up the Nile: Egypt in 19th Century Photographs
exhibition_description: This exhibition features early photographic images made along the north-flowing Nile River, from Nubia to Lower Egypt. They meticulously depict the country’s renowned ancient monuments at such sites as Philae, Luxor, Karnak, and Giza. Dating from the late-nineteenth century, the photographs were made by professional photographers for tourists who flocked to Egypt on their “Grande Tour.” The exhibition consists of about fifty albumen prints by a half dozen photographers, including Felice Beato, Felix Bonfils, and Francis Frith. The work is drawn entirely from the Institute’s permanent collection and compliments the concurrent exhibition “Eternal Egypt.”

exhibition_title: Walker Evans
exhibition_description: Walker Evans’s crisp, authoritative images helped define the documentary style of photography that flourished between the World Wars. Working for the U.S. government in the 1930s, Evans created his most significant body of work, essaying the vernacular architecture and rural poor of the Deep South. This exhibition consisted of about fifty of these stunning, vintage photographs. They were drawn entirely from the Institute’s permanent collection, which has one of the country’s most significant holdings of Evans’s work. A catalogue accompanied the exhibition.

exhibition_title: Long Afternoon: Celeste Nelms and Carolyn Swiszcz
exhibition_description: “Long Afternoon” featured new work by Celeste Nelms and Carolyn Swiszcz, two artists who share an uncommon affection for things well past their prime. In their exhibition of photographs and mixed media paintings, they both paid homage to things created and treasured, later caste off or forgotten.

exhibition_title: "Art That's Really Moving" and "Can't Leave it Alone"
exhibition_description:
Timothy Fort’s “Art That’s Really Moving” featured ongoing footage of Fort’s kinetic arrangements. Tim Fort is obsessed with the magic of static objects coming to life and has designed hundreds of domino tumbles and exploding Popsicle sticks and playing card sculpture. 

Gerald Smith’s “Can’t Leave it Alone” presented a working studio, including evidence of past work, a host of artificial satellites and silent documentary films. Smith’s studio centered on a work-in-progress about the science of human cloning, that premiered during the run of the show.

exhibition_title: George Washington: A National Treasure
exhibition_description: The 205-year-old portrait of George Washington is considered an American treasure compared to that of the Liberty Bell and the Declaration of Independence. It is commonly called the “Lansdowne” portrait, the title derived from the name of the person for whom it was painted, the Marquis of Lansdowne. Senator William Bingham commissioned it in 1796 for the marquis, a British support of the American cause during the American Revolution. The artist is Gilbert Stuart, the preeminent portraitist in the United States in the early 19th century. Stuart painted nearly 1,000 portraits in his lifetime including Paul Revere, Abigail Adams, Mohawk Chief Joseph Brandt as well as George Washington and numerous other U.S. presidents. In spring of 2001 the National Portrait Gallery acquired the “Lansdowne” portrait through a generous gift from the Donald W. Reynolds Foundation.

exhibition_title: Werner Bischof: Life and Work of a Photographer 1916 - 1954
exhibition_description: Born in Zürich, Switzerland 26 April 1916, Werner Bischof began his career in studio photography. Following service in the Swiss army, he documented Europe in the aftermath of World War II. The devastation he recorded there was to influence his work for the rest of his life. He joined the Magnum Photographic agency in 1949 and continued to focus on the ‘face of human suffering’. One of his most well known photo-essays on ‘Famine in India’ was published in Life magazine the same year. He also completed assignments in Korea, Okinawa and Japan. He covered the stories of refugees from Mao’s China and the war in Indochina. Werner Bischof died in May 1954 at the age of 38 while on assignment for Magnum and Life in Peru. This exhibition included more than 65 prints covering the Studio Period, Europe After the War and Traveling the World.

exhibition_title: P.R.S.S.
Chaim Soutine
Recent Acquisitions - November 2003 - April 2004
exhibition_description: This exhibition featured a selection of some of the MIA’s most notable recent acquisitions.

exhibition_title: Holiday Traditions: A White House Christmas
exhibition_description:
Since Calvin Coolidge lit the first official White House Christmas tree in 1923, American presidents have communicated holiday greetings through public addresses, cards, prints, and other gifts. This year's "Holiday Traditions" offered insight into Christmas at the White House. The Bell Family Decorative Arts Court featured mementos from the 1930s to the present, including the card for which this Wyeth painting was commissioned, and a rare example of the card signed by President Kennedy just days before his assassination.

Costumed guides offer tours of the Bell Court and the Period Rooms several times each day.

exhibition_title: Beauty, Honor, and Tradition: The Legacy of Plains Indian Shirts

exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art
exhibition_title: The Miller Collection of Roman Sculpture: Mythological Figures and Protraits
exhibition_description: This refined exhibition of Roman sculpture features over thirty stone portraits dating from the first through third centuries. Selected from the private holdings of New York collector Dr. Michael Miller, the show is comprised of three-dimensional heads, relief fragments, and full figures. Features in the display are royal portraits including those of emperors Diocletian and Caesar Augustus; several private portraits of the aristocracy as well as a group of mythological portraits including Hercules, Cupid, and Zeus. The exhibit provides the viewer a fascinating look at some of the personalities, intriguing iconography, and refined sculpting techniques of classical antiquity that are not available in the museum’s permanent collection of Roman sculpture. This thematic exhibit appeals tremendously to scholars and students of Roman art and anyone interested in classical history and art. A fully illustrated catalogue by Dr. Richard Brilliant accompanies the exhibition.

exhibition_title: Currents of Change: Art and Life Along the Mississippi River, 1850-1861
exhibition_description:
America’s development was at one of its most dramatic moments in the 1850s, a decade celebrated along the Mississippi River as the 50th anniversary of the Louisiana Purchase and the westward expedition of Lewis and Clark. Currents of Change will explore the fine and decorative arts along the river during that period. America was undergoing extraordinary changes: from the steamboat era to the advent of the railroad, from a mostly agrarian economy to the beginnings of the industrial revolution, from a nation of youthful optimism to one which would soon erupt into civil war. Fortunes made from lumber and lead processing in the North and cotton and sugar production in the South gave birth to the great cities along the river that we know today, and financed the demand for sophisticated furnishings and a “refined” life. The Mississippi, which had long been a channel for trade, was becoming an important conduit for ideas about art, culture, and design.
Currents of Change brings together approximately 175 objects in all media: paintings, prints, and drawings, furniture, silver, ceramics, textiles, and sculpture. The exhibition includes a 16-foot segment from the only extant panorama of the Mississippi River (a 340-foot-long moving landscape), to be shown in a theatrical setting that recalls how viewers of the 1850s would have seen it.
An illustrated catalogue accompanies the exhibition.

venues.venue: Louisiana State University Museum of Art

exhibition_title: Beauford Delaney: From New York to Paris
exhibition_description: Beauford Delaney, an African-American, was an artist who produced works of great diversity and technical complexity who has, unfortunately, remained relatively unknown to the general public. While his pursuit of art began in his native Knoxville, Tennessee, and continued over a five-year period in Boston, the years that followed (1929-1979) were the most innovative and productive of the artist’s life. His career is generally broken into two parts: the New York Years (1929-1953), during which time Delaney produced his colorful and highly-engaging compositions of the City’s urban landscape; and the Paris years (1953-1979) when the artist, known as “the dean of American Negro painters” in Paris, embraced abstract expressionism in a study of color and light. The Institute’s presentation, for the first time, provides a survey of the progression of his work. The exhibition brings forth transitional works that have not previously been considered and illuminate his place within American art history. The exhibition consists of approximately forty paintings and ten works on paper borrowed from institutional and private collections in America and Europe.

exhibition_title: Holiday Traditions
exhibition_description:
Packages of all sorts have come a long way since the plain brown bundles depicted in Victorian Christmas scenes. Advances in construction, printing, and mechanization throughout the 20th century have resulted in “graphic” developments for the simple shopping bag and hatbox.  They serves as portable billboards for the store, and once home, can live on as containers for keepsakes—often becoming keepsakes themselves. As department stores and boutiques increasingly consider packaging as an extension of their service and identity, they look to designers for more attractive wrappings. Artists such as Erté, Roy Lichtenstein, Salvador Dali, Andy Warhol, and Frank Stella have accepted commissions to design shopping bags, many of them considered portable art by museums and collectors.  
In the Twin Cities, such fashion-forward retailers as Young-Quinlan, Field-Schlick, and Dayton’s invested considerable effort and imagination into their packaging. The Institute will feature these and other designs from local shops in the Bell Decorative Arts Court during this year’s Holiday Traditions exhibition, on view in the Period Rooms and at the Purcell-Cutts house November 26, 2004 through January 2, 2005. Costumed docents will offer tours from Thanksgiving through New Year’s Eve.

exhibition_title: Lyonel Feininger
A Man and His Garden: Textiles from the Jack Lenor Larsen Archive
Jan Van Der Streadanus: 16th Century Flemish Engravings and Woodcuts

Eduardo Paolozzi's 'Moonstrips Empire News'
Illuminating the Word: The Saint John's Bible
exhibition_description: The Saint John’s Bible exhibition consists of 60 of the more than 200 Bible pages that are being created for the first handwritten, illuminated Bible from the modern era. Scribes in a Wales scriptorium under the artistic direction of Donald Jackson, one of the world’s foremost calligraphers and the Scribe to Queen Elizabeth are creating the Bible. The Bible incorporates many of the characteristics of its medieval predecessors: it is be written on vellum, using quills, natural handmade inks, hand-ground pigments, and gild, such as gold leaf. It, however, employs a modern English translation as well as contemporary scripts and illumination.

exhibition_title: Paul Klee im Rheinland
Untamed Beauty: Tigers in  Japanese Art
exhibition_description:
The tiger figures prominently in Asian mythology, where it is identified with yin, the female principle, as well as autumn, wind, and the west. Artists often paired images of tigers with their cosmological cousin, the dragon (identified with yang, the male principle, spring, rain, and the east). Although tigers are not indigenous to Japan, their absence engendered great interest in them and spurred fanciful ideas about their nature and physical form. The earliest Japanese images of tigers date to as early as the 6th century, but the subject became a staple theme of artists from the 13th century onwards. Some artists pictured ferocious beasts in windswept bamboo; others rendered tigers as overgrown housecats.  This exhibition explores the great breadth of tiger painting through the fertile imaginations of twenty-one Japanese artists. 
From 1959 until 1964, Edson Spencer was Far East regional manager for Honeywell International in Tokyo. While in Japan, both he and his wife, Harriet, became enamored with Japanese art and amassed an important collection of folk painting. This collection was featured in the museum’s 1994 exhibition Øtsu-e: Japanese Folk Paintings. 
Born in the “year of the tiger” Edson Spencer purchased his first tiger painting while living in Japan. Since then, his collection has grown to include 21 hanging scrolls and a magnificent pair of folding screens. Artists include many of Japan’s most famous painters of the last three hundred years, including Tawaraya Sotatsu, Maruyama Okyo, Nagasawa Rosetsu, Kano Tsunenobu, and Kishi Ganku

exhibition_title: The Quiet Landscapes of William B. Post
exhibition_description:
This exhibition consists of 60 subtle landscape photographs dating 1890-1910, drawn entirely from the Institute's permanent collection. Post (1857-1921) was one of the first photographers to make creative images with the camera, associating with Alfred Stieglitz and presenting his pictures in the leading photographic periodical, Camera Work. Post excelled at picturing the snow, water lilies, and apple trees of Maine, rendering them in softly-focused and understated platinum prints. This exhibition rediscovers an underappreciated master, will be accompanied by a catalog, and will travel to other American museums.
Exhibition tour:
The Minneapolis Institute of Arts, September 10, 2005 – January 22, 2006
Cedar Rapids Museum of Art, February 17 - May 21, 2006
Portland Museum of Art, June 3 - Aug. 27, 2006
Columbus Museum of Art, September 16, 2006 – January 14, 2007
Brigham Young University Museum of Art, February 3 - June 4, 2007
Tacoma Art Museum, June 23 – September 16, 2007

Times Squared: Photographs by Toby Old
exhibition_description: Old’s work has always been characterized by a solid technical mastery of the medium format camera as the tool for his wonderfully zany, insightful and intelligent observation of the American scene. His subjects range from public events and situations such as Coney Island and Times Square, to county fairs, street theater, and professional boxing. Also included are images of the New York nightclub scene of the 1970s, fashion shows, and other displays of vanity and public preening. The photographs evoke an amusing though gently caustic, tongue-in-cheek satire on how we present ourselves to the world.

A Woman's Way: Feminine Attire in 20th Century Morocco
exhibition_description: This exhibition featured objects drawn from the Textiles and Africa, Oceania, and the Americas collections as well as selected pieces from a private collection. The focus of the installation is on Berber, Jewish, and Arab influences on female clothing styles of rural and urban Moroccan women during the 20th century. Changing styles and cultural adaptations were shown featuring festive and holiday clothing.

exhibition_title: Art in Rome in the Eighteenth Century
Symphony in Black and White: 100 Etchings and Lithographs of James McNeill Whistler
exhibition_description: James Abbott McNeill Whistler died on July 17, 1903, making this year the centenary of his death. This exhibition celebrated the career and life of this extraordinary artist. The Minneapolis Institute of Arts has over 100 etchings and lithographs by Whistler that formed the core of the exhibition. As an etcher, Whistler took inspiration from Rembrandt and the Dutch masters that he discovered in the print collection of his brother in law, Francis Seymour Haden. Works by these artists were on view, allowing the visitor to see the path of Whistler's development as a printmaker. Whistler was a charismatic and challenging personality whose art and ideas influenced numerous other artists. This exhibition also included works by those who were members of Whistler's circle of admirers and followers, allowing the visitor to see the wide path Whistler cut across the art world. His influence was not only seen in the prints and paintings of the day, but also in the interiors and decorative arts his gathered around him. The exhibition was augmented by a selection of decorative arts, Japanese prints, and other objects that would have graced a Whisterian interior. The exhibition cut across numerous curatorial departments to create a stunning picture of the world of James Abbott McNeill Whistler.

exhibition_title: Cloth Only Wears to Shreds: Textiles and Photographs from the Ulli Beier Collection
Joan Miró
European Muses, American Masters: 1870 to 1950
Cotton Puffs, Q-Tips, Smoke and Mirrors: The Drawings of Ed Ruscha
The Twin Cities Collects: The Ceramics of Edwin and Mary Scheier
exhibition_description: Americans Edwin and Mary Scheier (b. 1910 and b. 1908) took a circuitous route to the world of pottery, by way of art school, odd jobs, puppeteering, and positions with the Works Progress Administration during the 1930s. By 1940 their lively pots of Virginia clay won awards at the prestigious Ceramic National at Syracuse, New York. As a result, Ed was offered a teaching position at the University of New Hampshire, where he and Mary produced hundreds of beautifully potted wares often decorated with Ed’s expressive human figures or abstract sgraffito decoration. In the late 1960s, the Scheiers’ move to Mexico resulted in exciting work in new media including weaving design and wooden sculpture. After the Scheiers settled in Arizona in 1978, Ed returned with renewed vigor to clay and has over the past several years created original computer art. This exhibition, celebrated the wealth of work by the Scheiers in local public and private collections, included approximately forty-five ceramic pieces, as well as other objects in a variety of media from their 60-plus years as a creative team.
