Multiple Personalities: Figural Sculpture and Contemporary Craft
exhibition_description: Beginning in the 1950s, artists working in traditional craft media transitioned away from the vessel form into sculpture, a move that liberated following generations of artists. This exhibition explores how artists working in traditional craft media have developed unique approaches to sculpting the human figure, and in the process blurred the distinctions between the two disciplines. It will feature some of the MIA’s most significant examples from the past three decades, by such notable artists as Robert Arneson, Stephen De Staebler, and Viola Frey in clay, and Stoney Lamar and Robyn Horn in wood.

exhibition_title: Picturing History: Paintings and Studies of Art, Artifacts, Furniture and Architecture of the Minneapolis Institute of Arts by Richard Rock
exhibition_description: Formalism meets conceptualism in this exhibit, which explores the museum experience. Richard Rock painted in the galleries of the Minneapolis Institute of Art since 2001. His small oil paintings depict installations of the Asian and European galleries. Rock paints "history from life" to connect with the minds of the many historical artisans whose works are included in the museum’s permanent collection. Abinadi Meza records the sounds of the museum to give visitors the opportunity to experience the sonic life of the MIA. Using standard and contact microphones, he records museum activity to create a sonic collage presented looped as a multi-channel sound installation.

exhibition_title: Abinadi Meza: Found Voice, Solo Museum
Framing: "Alec Soth: Sleeping by the Mississippi"
Friedlander: Photography
exhibition_description: Comprised of six early color portraits, nearly 500 black-and-white gelatin silver prints, and approximately 50 examples of Friedlander’s books, special editions, and portfolios, Friedlander: Photography traces a prolific career that continues to thrive after half a century. Supplemented by a modest number of loans from the artist, the retrospective is largely drawn from the Museum of Modern Art’s extensive collection of Friedlander’s work. There are groups of photographs, each narrowly tailored by date, theme, and style. Groups that present distilled versions of Friedlander’s books are identified as such. Completing the exhibition are seven displaying Friedlander’s portfolios and special editions. A fully illustrated catalogue accompanies the exhibition.

exhibition_title: Hail to the Chief: Images of the American Presidency
exhibition_description:
This exhibition is being organized to coincide with the 2008 Republican National Convention, which will convene in Minneapolis-Saint Paul on September 1-4, 2008. 
Designed from a non-partisan perspective, the exhibition will feature a selection of original works of art and other material that explores or depicts themes and subjects associated with the Presidency of the United States of America and those individuals who have held the office of the President. The exhibition will comprise approximately 50-70 objects in a range of media, including paintings, sculpture, drawings, prints, posters, photographs, manuscripts, and various types of decorative arts objects, including glassware, porcelain, and metalwork. There will be a complementary group of Presidential-related objects, which may include such items as signed photographs, letters, greeting cards, campaign literature and other material, flags, banners, etc. 
The exhibition will include works drawn from the MIA’s permanent collection and from the private collection of Kim Anderson of North Oaks, Minnesota. Mr. Anderson co-owns an extensive collection of presidential-related items and memorabilia. Among the categories of objects to be displayed are presidential portraits and busts; candid photographs of former Presidents and presidential candidates; newspaper illustrations and accounts; images of the White House; presidential proclamations and letters; government-issued posters with themes associated with the Presidency; decorative arts depicting images of former presidents; and presidential campaign material.

exhibition_title: Artist Couples - Love, Art and Passion
Kenneth Callahan
Becoming Edvard Munch: Influence, Anxiety, and Myth
Tom Arndt's Minnesota
exhibition_description: Tom Arndt (born 1944) has persistently chronicled everyday life in Minnesota since the early 1970s. His straightforward and insightful black-and-white images span the state geographically, emotionally, and spiritually. He covered the vice-presidential campaign of Walter Mondale in 1984, has photographed the State Fair for years, and is most at home with ordinary Minnesotans on the street and in their homes. Thomas Frederick Arndt is Minnesota’s leading documentary photography of the last thirty-five years. The exhibition will include 75 photographs from the MIA permanent collection and the artist. A fully illustrated catalogue accompanies the exhibition.

exhibition_title: Smoke and Mirrors | Vance Gellert
exhibition_description: As a photographer and a scientist, Vance Gellert has traveled to Bolivia and Peru to observe native healing rituals, environments and plants. The photographs and actual healing objects from these journeys of discovery evoke a spirit of place, culture and healing traditions. They transcend cultural differences to create a receptive and stimulating environment in which to consider new directions and methodology in health care. His exhibition illustrates how art can contribute to scientific understanding of our world.

exhibition_title: The Christmas Story
Seventeenth Century Dutch Masterpieces
Dutch Masterpieces

Autour de Claude-Joseph Vernet, la marine a voile de 1650 a 1890
Realism in Painting and Sculpture
Insult and Injury: Elaborations on Christ's Passion
exhibition_description: In Germany and the Low Countries, Christ’s Passion was relived many times daily in the minds of the faithful. The Passion was the most highly venerated subject during the fifteenth and much of the sixteenth centuries, a phenomenon characterized by high-strung devotions and empathetic emotionalism. Popular Passion tracts encouraged such meditations by elaborating on Gospel events with wholly invented miseries, designed to intensify people’s empathy for Christ’s suffering. As this exhibition shows, printmakers followed suit, adding new forms of torture, inventive coloring, and other wrenching devices to heighten the drama of Christ’s sacrifice.

exhibition_title: Trafalgar Galleries at the Royal Academy IV
Robert Rauschenberg: Prints/Editions 1962-78
exhibition_description:
Robert Rauschenberg’s recent death at age eighty-two ended the long and vibrant career of one of America’s pre-eminent contemporary artists. 
This exhibition examines the artist’s early activities producing original prints, multiples, and artist’s books in collaboration with many of America’s leading print workshops. Selected from the MIA’s extensive collection of twentieth-century graphic art, the exhibition features more than thirty examples of Rauschenberg’s editioned work from this key period.

exhibition_title: Outside Influences: Jack Lenor Larsen and African Aesthetics
exhibition_description: This exhibition contrasts Larsen’s African Collection with authentic African textiles.

exhibition_title: Unconventional Wisdom
exhibition_description: Ruthann Godollei and Mike Elko are print makers with sardonic senses of humor. Godollei’s work comments on inequities, injustices and disparities via a series of symbolic containers and household items. Elko transforms idealized images of American life, family and politics into sly observations on contemporary culture.

exhibition_title: Millions of Innocent Accidents
exhibition_description: Hardland/Heartland, a creative group helmed by Eric Carlson and Aaron Anderson, offer a post-apocalyptic vision of the Midwest. Their mixed-media installations incorporate artists working in a variety of media from design, music, fashion, film, sculpture and architecture. Straddling the lines between the real and the fantastic HL/HL’s narrative installations bend and twist with the will of participants and viewer.

exhibition_title: The Most Beautiful Museum in the World
After the Photo-Secession: American Pictorial Photography, 1910-1955
exhibition_description: This exhibition examined the social and artistic development of pictorial photography between the World Wars. Approximately 150 photographs, characterized by their accessible subject matter, manipulative techniques, and beautiful imagery are included in the show and are by such artists as D.J. Ruzicka, Adolf Fassbender, A. Aubrey Bodine, Eleanor Parke Curtis, Frank Roy Fraprie, William Mortensen, P.H. Oelman, Harry K. Shigeta, and Max Thorek. This was the first major exhibition on this subject matter and travels to a number of American museums after its presentation in Minneapolis. A major publication accompanied this exhibition.

Jaromír Funke and the Amateur Avant-Garde
Beyond the Maker's Mark: Paul de Lamerie Silver in the Cahn Collection
exhibition_description:
Beyond the Maker’s Mark celebrates the extraordinary work of London’s leading eighteenth-century silversmith, Paul de Lamerie (1688-1751). Through the private collection of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Cahn—which includes some of the most important pieces of de Lamerie silver in private hands—the exhibition explores several aspects of de Lamerie’s career, revealing the evolution of his style and the complex organization of his enterprise.
The exhibition, organized by the Memphis Brooks Museum of Art, features nearly one hundred individual examples of Rococo English silver by de Lamerie and his contemporaries, such as the superb Maynard Dish (1736) and the extraordinary Tureen in the Shape of a Green Turtle (1750). This venue will include several Paul de Lamerie pieces from the MIA collection, including the magnificent Wine Cistern (1719-20). A fully illustrated catalogue accompanies the exhibition.

exhibition_title: Kunstwelten im Dialog
Noble Dreams & Simple Pleasures: American Masterworks from Minnesota Collections
exhibition_description:
Art collections around the Twin Cities offer a rich selection of American art spanning from the 18th century to contemporary art. This is the first exhibition drawing purely on American works in local collections (roughly covering the years from 1800 to 1920).

The exhibition will include approximately 140 works, composed primarily of paintings and supplemented with some sculptures and works on paper.  Objects will be presented fairly chronologically along the following themes; Folk Art, Early Minnesota, Hudson River School, The Transatlantics, Tonalism, Minnesota Painters, On the Cusp.

A small publication comprised of an essay giving a brief overview of private collecting in Minnesota, along with selected works will be produced.

exhibition_title: Alexander Roslin and the Comtesse d'Egmont Pignatelli
exhibition_description: This exhibition places our recent acquisition, Alexander Roslin's "The Comtesse d'Egmont Pignatelli in Spanish Costume" in a deeper art historical context. Supplementary works in paintings and sculpture explore the sitter's relationship to the artist, her ties to the French court of Louis XV and Swedish court of Gustaf III, as well as her involvement with the intellectual and cultural circles of the French Salons.

exhibition_title: The Art and Wit of Caricature: The English Tradition
exhibition_description: This exhibition of forty caricature prints and drawings from the MIA’s permanent collection presents social satire that both bristles and entertains. It examines the comic art form in eighteenth-century England, in the work of some of the period’s most celebrated caricaturists-William Hogarth (1697-1764), Thomas Rowlandson (1756-1827), and James Gillray (1756-1815).

exhibition_title: Eero Saarinen: Shaping the Future
exhibition_description: This exhibition is part of a comprehensive project that explores the work of one of the most prolific, unorthodox, and controversial modern masters of 20th-century architecture and design. Finnish-born Saarinen (1910-1961) is best known for such modern icons as the Jefferson National Expansion Memorial (Gateway Arch) in St. Louis, Missouri (designed 1948, completed 1964), the Trans World Airlines Terminal at JFK Airport in New York City, and Dulles International Airport in Chantilly, Virginia (both completed 1962). Saarinen’s presence in the Midwest is very strong, with his creation of corporate campuses for General Motors (Technical Center, Warren, Michigan, completed 1956) and IBM (Rochester, Minnesota, completed 1959), as well as churches and campus projects including his collaboration with his famous architect father, Eliel, on Christ Church Lutheran in Minneapolis, Minnesota (1949). By examining the architect’s entire output of more than 50 built and proposed projects, Eero Saarinen: Shaping the Future will be the first opportunity to understand Saarinen’s collective work in the larger context of postwar modern architecture. It will also address his sculptural furniture, including the famous “Womb” chair Eero designed in 1948 for Knoll. The exhibition will be organized into two sections: “Building for Postwar America,” shown at the MIA will focus on building types, illustrating the wide range of Saarinen’s projects in the context of their cultural and political significance; and “The Architect and his Milieu,” shown at the Walker will examine Saarinen and his many collaborators including designers Charles Eames, and Alexander Girard, and local architect Ralph Rapson.

exhibition_title: The Art and Wit of Caricature: Honoré Daumier
exhibition_description: The lithographs of Honoré Daumier reveal his flair for gesture and facial expression and his ability to recognize the comedy of everyday life. This exhibition presents a selection of his satirical images from the MIA collection.

exhibition_title: Masterpiece Photographs from the Minneapolis Institute of Arts: The Curatorial Legacy of Carroll T. Hartwell
exhibition_description:
The Minneapolis Institute of Arts has the Upper Midwest’s most significant permanent collection of fine photographs. Numbering about 10,000 photographs, it covers the entire history of the medium, from the mid-nineteenth century to the present day.
This exhibition features the fifty most salient and fully-realized photographs in the museum’s holdings. It begins with a 1845 salt print by the English inventor William Henry Fox Talbot and ends with a 2002 color portrait by Alec Soth, from his series “Sleeping by the Mississippi.” In between, the genres of documentary photography, photo-journalism, and street photography are well represented in the show. Included are Dorothea Lange’s “Migrant Mother” and Arthur Rothstein’s “Dust Storm,” both iconic images from the Great Depression. Among the most recognizable pictures are Edward Weston’s “Pepper No. 30” (1930) and Ansel Adams’s “Moonrise, Hernandez” (1941). The names of other photographers represented reads like a who’s who of photography: Berenice Abbott, Diane Arbus, Eugene Atget, Richard Avedon, Walker Evans, Robert Frank, Lee Friedlander, Lewis W. Hine, Man Ray, W. Eugene Smith, Alfred Stieglitz, and Paul Strand.
This is the first time that the Minneapolis Institute of Arts has presented such a highly-selected grouping of its most important photographs. The exhibition and its accompanying publication commemorate the significant collecting legacy of Carroll T. (Ted) Hartwell, the founding curator of the department, who died in 2007. It reveals Mr. Hartwell’s critical eye for singular historical pieces as well as his belief in the influence and vitality of accomplished living photographers. A fully illustrated catalogue accompanies the exhibition.

exhibition_title: Strange Ornament from the Renaissance Mind
exhibition_description: This exhibition comprises more than two dozen Renaissance prints featuring extravagantly imagined ornament designs—for dishes, tankards, columns, and more—which are both pretty and grotesque.

exhibition_department: Art of Africa and the Americas
exhibition_title: Time and Tide: The Changing Art of the Asmat of New Guinea
exhibition_description: This exhibition will highlight the artistic output of the Asmat, a native people of western New Guinea. Its theme is the distinct and powerful aesthetic sense of this group, and its expression in a number of art forms, especially sculpture, fiber arts and decorative painting. Asmat art is very distinctive, frequently employing abstract, curvilinear designs in exhilarating combinations. These designs are highlighted by a strong palette, consisting of just three colors; red, white and black. Figural sculpture is often adorned with color as well. The exhibition will consist of objects made by Asmat artists, primarily from the collection of the American Museum of Asmat Art at the University of St. Thomas. Wood sculpture and fiber arts will comprise the majority of the exhibit. A fully illustrated catalogue accompanies the exhibition.

exhibition_title: Holiday Traditions
exhibition_description:
Since 1951, the MIA has decorated its American and European period rooms each year to show winter holidays as they were celebrated in times past. Nine period rooms showcase a range of special occasions, from a feast in Tudor England to a 1770s Hanukkah celebration in Providence, Rhode Island. Examples of early Christmas trees and Nativity scenes are highlighted in the Bell Family Decorative Arts Court and the Mary C. and Walter C. Briggs Gallery. To further explore Hanukkah this year, a display of contemporary Hanukkah lamps will be on display near the Providence Room.

As well, the MIA’s Prairie-School style Purcell-Cutts House, designed in 1913 by William Gray Purcell and George Grant Elmslie for Purcell and his family, is decorated for the holidays to reflect the upper-middle-class, “progressive” lifestyle of the Purcells around 1915.

exhibition_title: Art and the Empire City: The Visual Arts in New York, 1825-1861
Journey to the Surface of the Earth
exhibition_description:
Margaret Pezalla-Granlund’s and Max Schollett’s works begin with common objects. Pezalla-Granlund has explored icebergs, parking ramps and skate parks. She recreates these objects in paper, photographing them at various stages of construction and deconstruction. Observing these mathematical models and their relationship to the geometry of our real world, she documents the complexities of navigating the spaces around us.
Max Schollett explores the relationship between effort, value and aesthetics in his altered objects through an intense focus of time and labor. Objects hover on the precipice between literal and acquired meaning, so that the object exists between the everyday and the unfamiliar.

exhibition_title: Un grande maestro da riscoprire: Gregorio Guglielmi, pittore romano del Settecento

Expanded Drawing
exhibition_description: Nicholas Conberre, Michelle Johnson, Jack Pavlik and Sonja Peterson extend their use of line and the concept of drawing. Conberre’s invented landscapes of layered drawings and photos create complex, dreamlike panoramas. Johnson’s repetitive, overlapping patterns of calligraphic letters distort the original mark and create a new aesthetic identity. Pavik’s kinetic sculptures create visual and aural narratives of form and movement. Peterson’s cut-out drawings farmland and wildlife play with ideas of perception and reality.

Swiss Graphic Design: Precision and Presence
exhibition_description:
The year 2009 marks the 20th annual Modernism exhibition presented at Wells Fargo Center in downtown Minneapolis. To commemorate the anniversary, Wells Fargo Minnesota has donated a series of twenty Swiss posters — emblematic of the Swiss International Style dating from 1950 -1985 — to the Minneapolis Institute of Arts.
A haven for artists fleeing two world wars, neutral Switzerland formulated a distinct advertising style with special emphasis on the poster format. Swiss artists had been exposed earlier to the move-ments and styles flourishing elsewhere in Europe, yet it was not until the late twenties that the Swiss poster exemplified a universally recognized signature style.
The active encouragement of poster design by the Swiss government at national and local levels and the institution of an annual competition to promote it were significant, as were such important journals as Graphis (founded in 1944) and Neue Grafik (New Graphic Design) founded in 1958. Replete with articles summarizing the major tenets of the Swiss Style, it was responsible for establishing Switzerland’s reputation as the epicenter of modernist typography. Moreover, the schools of applied arts in Basel and Zurich became internationally important education centers for graphic design.
Swiss designers developed a number of new typefaces in the 1950s, the most popular and celebrated being Helvetica,* a refined version of Akzidenz Grotesk, a 19th-century sans-serif typeface. Helvetica’s widespread use became integral to the clarity and easy legibility of the Swiss graphic style. In fact, sans-serif type was the most emblematic component of the International Typographic Style. In 1954, Adrian Foutiger designed Univers, a mathe-matically constructed and visually programmed font with twenty-one variations.
Among the younger Swiss designers who emerged in the 1950s through the ’70s as important innovators were: Armin Hofmann (his 1965 book, “Graphic Design Manual,” was a key manifesto of elementary design principles), Tino Steinemann, Car

exhibition_title: Holy Land: Sara Belleau
exhibition_description:
Sara Belleau and Nancy Robinson tap myth and folklore archetypes to tell tales both personal and universal. 

Belleau’s photographs capture hand painted backgrounds and constructed sets that conjure elaborate tales. Her "Holy Land" series brings ancient stories from the Bible, Torah and Koran to life in a modern Minnesota vernacular. Drawing on stories common throughout to each of these texts, she explores shared traditions and cultures juxtaposed against the complicated political/social present.

Robinson’s boldly colored self-portraits create a stage in which she stars as a variety of iconic characters that are both humorous and surrealistic. Each character she embodies a distilled memory that transforms her life story into fable.

exhibition_title: Sin and Guilt, Paintings by Nancy Robinson
exhibition_description:
Sara Belleau and Nancy Robinson tap myth and folklore archetypes to tell tales both personal and universal. 

Belleau’s photographs capture hand painted backgrounds and constructed sets that conjure elaborate tales. Her "Holy Land" series brings ancient stories from the Bible, Torah and Koran to life in a modern Minnesota vernacular. Drawing on stories common throughout to each of these texts, she explores shared traditions and cultures juxtaposed against the complicated political/social present.

Robinson’s boldly colored self-portraits create a stage in which she stars as a variety of iconic characters that are both humorous and surrealistic. Each character she embodies a distilled memory that transforms her life story into fable.

exhibition_department: Art of Africa and the Americas
exhibition_title: iAfrica: Connecting with Sub-Saharan Art
exhibition_description:
This exhibition is an experiment with different ways to display and explain African art. It will be comprised of around fifteen objects, primarily sculptures, taken mainly from the MIA’s collection, that will be shown in various kinds of settings, for example with different sorts of captions, with or without contextual photos, etc. The different settings will explore degrees of accessibility of the objects, amounts of information offered, the use of audio-visual aids, and other “parameters.”
A crucial part of the exhibition will be the reactions – comments, criticism, and suggestions – from the different audiences. The kind of questions to be asked, and the ways in which to respond, will be determined in close association with MIA’s Education and Interactive Media departments.

exhibition_title: Josef Sudek and Czech Photography
exhibition_description: Josef Sudek (1896-1976) is Czechoslovakia’s most well-known and influential creative photographer. He worked from the 1910s through the 1960s, producing ethereal landscapes, modernist still lifes, and sweeping panoramas of the city of Prague. Every subsequent Czech photographer acknowledged Sudek’s pioneering work and contributed, in their own way, to the rich photographic legacy of their country. Among them were the modernists Frantisek Drtikol and Jaromir Funke, the surrealist Eva Fuka, and the contemporary figure-photographer Jan Saudek. These and other individuals working in what is now the Czech Republic created one of the strongest contributions to twentieth-century photography in all of Europe. The exhibition will include approximately 75 photographs drawn entirely from the MIA’s holdings and the local collection of Harry Drake.

exhibition_title: A Constant Line: Don Myhre and Cherlye Melander
exhibition_description:
Cheryl Melander’s and Donald Myhre’s sculptures explore memory and the ways we contextualize the past in the present.
Melander’s work investigates involuntary memory, which emphasizes the symbiotic relationship of body and mind. Through repetition, non-linear narratives, and patterns, she creates meditative environments that evaluate time. Constructing landscapes she explores the possibility that there could be genetically transferred memories and behaviors that are rediscovered and found through a methodology of free association. 
Myhre’s work is made to prompt memory of witnessed events by building an object to commemorate its importance. They are ‘self made’ souvenirs that authenticate an experience and allow embellishment of specific aspects of each occurrence. Carefully chosen materials, objects and processes make a clear representation, but the resulting piece is usually a nostalgic replica rather than a factually correct object.

exhibition_title: The Night Sky in the Age of Vermeer: The Astronomer in Context
Photographer to the Tsar: Revealing the Silk Road
Afro Modern: Journeys Through the Black Atlantic
Ernst Ludwig Kirchner
From Towers to Teakettles: Michael Graves Architecture and Design
exhibition_description:
Over a career spanning more than 40 years, Michael Graves has developed an individual approach to architecture and design that combines his love of classical forms and elements with a sense of sophisticated wit.  This exhibition, organized on the occasion of the ten-year anniversary of Michael Graves Design for Target stores, will showcase Graves’s celebrated style and will also focus on the roles of context, accessibility, and total design in his work. 
 An architectural mini-retrospective section will represent a range of the firm’s projects, through models, drawings, and photographs, including the Fargo-Moorhead Cultural Bridge (1977), the Washington Monument Restoration (1998-2000), the Minneapolis Institute of Arts Target Wing (2006), and an extensive integrated resort in Sentosa, Singapore (2006 - present).  A section devoted to product design, which has literally made Graves a household name, will include his iconic whistling bird teakettle for Alessi (1985), jewelry designs for Belvedere (1991), selections from his “top 25” product designs for Target (1999-present), and a soon-to-be-launched line of accessibility products for Drive Medical.

We Believe in Some Thing: Roxanne Jackson
exhibition_description: Roxanne Jackson’s sculptural installations explore the duality of human nature through the metamorphosis of humans and animals. Her installations are macabre scenarios of predator vs. prey, good vs. evil, instinct and survival. Primarily a ceramicist, Jackson is experimenting with materials: glossy ceramic mouths pushing out of suede covered head forms or translucent rubber lit from within to suggest living, pulsing flesh. Her outdoor scenes filled with glowing eyed, hyenas and their victims are like stepping into the middle of the darkest of fairy tales.

exhibition_title: New Pictures 1: Noriko Furunishi

exhibition_department: Art of Africa and the Americas
exhibition_title: From Our Ancestors: Art of the White Clay People
exhibition_description:
This exhibition consists of objects attributed to the peoples of Fort Belknap Indian Reservation and the Northern Plains and will provide an exploration of the rich history, culture, and the arts of the A'aninin (Gros Ventre) and Nakoda (Assiniboine) peoples.
Fort Belknap Indian Reservation, home of the A’aninin tribe, is located in north-central Montana and is shared with the Nakoda. To the west of Fort Belknap lies the Blackfeet Indian Reservation, and to the north into Canada is the Cree tribe. This “triangle” of tribal groups influenced each other’s artwork based on color, technique, and design. The exhibition will explore the artistic and cultural relationships between these tribes.

exhibition_title: Holiday Traditions
exhibition_description:
Since 1951, the MIA has decorated its American and European period rooms each year to show winter holidays as they were celebrated in times past.  Nine period rooms showcase a range of special occasions, from a feast in Tudor England to a 1770s Hanukkah celebration in Providence, Rhode Island.  Examples of early Christmas trees and Nativity scenes are highlighted in the Bell Family Decorative Arts Court and the Mary C. and Walter C. Briggs Gallery.  To further explore the holidays this year, a selection of seasonal children’s books from the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries will be on view in the Bell Court.  Tours of the period rooms are led by costumed docents and are offered several times per day. For information on holiday tours of the period rooms, please call 612-870-3131.
As well, the MIA’s Prairie-School style Purcell-Cutts House, designed in 1913 by William Gray Purcell and George Grant Elmslie for Purcell and his family, is decorated for the holidays to reflect the upper-middle-class, “progressive” lifestyle of the Purcells around 1915.  Throughout the holidays, visitors can enjoy lively tours by costumed docents emphasizing the gifts, toys, food and social traditions of each period.  Tours of the Purcell-Cutts House, given on weekends from November 28 through January 3, can be reserved at 612 870-6323 or online.

Tauromachies: From Myth to Ritual

exhibition_title: To Make a World: George Ault and 1940s America
Dali: The Late Work
Elmyr de Hory, Artist and Faker
Until Now: Collecting the New (1960-2010)
exhibition_description:
Until Now: Collecting the New (1960-2010) is an in-depth look at international artistic activity from around the globe. The exhibition explores more than seventy-five works, including paintings, sculpture, prints, installation art, photography, and video, by artists; who have altered the direction of art during the past fifty years. While some of these pieces are in the museum’s permanent collection, most are on loan from artists, collectors, and galleries. The roster of artists, which incorporates modern masters as well as those emerging on the scene, includes Siah Armajani, Willie Cole, Mona Hatoum, David Hockney, Ilya Kabakov, Yayoi Kusama, Takashi Murakami, Claes Oldenburg, Nam June Paik, Cindy Sherman, Yinka Shonibare, and Andy Warhol, among many others.
Presenting a fresh vision of contemporary art, the exhibition also builds on the strengths of the museum’s renowned encyclopedic collection. Seeing contemporary art in the context of these diverse cultural forms and historical periods offers visitors new insights and perspectives on art’s ongoing significance and meaning. In conjunction with this special exhibition, a new program titled “Art Remix” features selected works of contemporary art installed throughout the museum in a variety of juxtapositions with the museum’s culturally rich and diverse historical holdings.
Until Now is organized around general themes that encompass a broad range of global art activity that cut across time, cultures, and other borders. Reflecting significant trends in the recent history of art, these themes include “New Poetics,” “Reviving Realism,” “Poptical,” “Recuperation,” and “Passages.”

exhibition_title: Chardin: 1699 - 1779
Europe's Exoticized East
“Scrap” by Michael Kareken
exhibition_description:
Michael Kareken latest body of work tackles the urban landscape, specifically the industrial recycling plants outside his studio window. His paintings are inspired by the never ending piles and constant movement of Rock-Tenn paper recycling plant and the American Iron metal scrap yard he finds metaphoric associations with life and death, growth and decay, order and entropy, structure and chaos. For the MAEP show, Kareken is creating these paintings on a grandiose scale, creating wall size vistas of these plants.

Tetsuya Yamada, on the other hand, works with the industrial landscape of production. Yamada’s work explores the intersection of ideas about the nature of art, craft, machine, and industry. Yamada now delves into the repetition and mundane activities of city life, specifically riding the train during his commutes in his native Tokyo. His installation will explore the way the human mind reacts to passive and repetitive acts, how our mind comes to accept the continuous rhythms of sights and sounds

exhibition_title: Commuter: Tetsuya Yamada
In Pursuit of a Masterpiece
exhibition_description: Over its long history, the permanent collection of the MIA has been studded with works of perfection. As the museum prepares for masterpieces chosen from every collecting department of the Louvre, MIA curators from all departments selected their own collection masterpieces. The exhibition is organized around the same themes as the Louvre exhibition and encourages visitors to think about the museum’s collection in different ways. In Pursuit of a Masterpiece and The Louvre and the Masterpiece together focus on the concept of “masterpiece,” and show how certain works of art have influenced generations.

exhibition_title: The Louvre and the Masterpiece
exhibition_description:
The Louvre and the Masterpiece will explore how the definition of a “masterpiece,” as well as taste and connoisseurship, have changed over time. The exhibition will feature sixty-two works of art drawn from all eight of the Musée du Louvre’s collection areas, spanning 4,000 years. Paintings, sculpture, decorative arts, and drawings will reflect three major themes: the changing historical and cultural definitions of a masterpiece; authenticity and connoisseurship; and the evolution of taste and scholarship.
The exhibition explores the changing historical definitions of a masterpiece through selections of objects from the ancient Near East through mid-nineteenth-century Europe and introduces the idea of connoisseurship as a means of identifying works from the past as masterpieces. It also examines masterpieces that were either rediscovered or reattributed based on the changing knowledge and perceptions of Louvre curators during the past two hundred years.
An in-depth examination of French sculptor Antoine-Louis Barye’s bronze Lion and Serpent further elucidates the exhibition themes, such as the significance of technical mastery and the creative process, and the impact of the artist’s reputation.

New Pictures 2: Marco Breuer
exhibition_description: Breuer removes both the camera and the traditional image. Instead, he strips photography to its essential materiality, and presents photographs that reveal physical actions on the surface of the light-sensitive paper. This gallery rotation is divided into two parts. Opening in February, Breuer will present selections of old and new works; then in mid-March, he will reorganize the gallery into a space that resembles a darkroom, emphasizing the artist’s process of creating a picture.

exhibition_title: Desire and Deliverance: Drama in the Old Testament
exhibition_description:
To coincide with the Science Museum of Minnesota's exhibition on the Dead Sea Scrolls, the MIA presents "Desire and Deliverance: Drama in the Old Testament," an exploration of how artists transformed biblical narratives of Noah, Jonah, Susanna, and others into scenes of passion, morality, piety, and nationalistic pride. 
The exhibition features biblical heroics and histrionics in prints and drawings from the 16th century and later, including Albrecht Dürer's inestimable Adam and Eve, eight Rembrandts, and several treasures on loan from The Thrivent Financial Collection of Religious Art.

exhibition_title: New Old Masters
exhibition_description:
The MIA continues its renewed commitment to contemporary art with the presentation of “New Old Masters,” an exhibition featuring a selection of prints of the 1960s and 70s by five internationally renowned American printmakers. Each of the featured artists—Jasper Johns, Ellsworth Kelly, Roy Lichtenstein, Frank Stella, and Andy Warhol—has left a unique and indelible mark on the development of contemporary art and printmaking during the second half of the twentieth century. Collectively, their influence is unparalleled. With their artistic legacies assured, we celebrate their achievement.
Highlights of the exhibition include Johns’s exquisite Periscope I (1979); Warhol’s famously grim Electric Chair portfolio (1971); and Lichtenstein’s fascinating Bull Profile series (1972), comprising a step-by-step progression from representation to pure abstraction.
The works of art in this exhibition have been generously loaned from a Twin Cities private collection.

exhibition_title: Rembrandt in America
exhibition_description:
During the Gilded Age, Americans developed an appetite for paintings by 17th-century Dutch master Rembrandt van Rijn. His paintings are now found in public and private collections from coast to coast. This exhibition will bring together one of the most substantial groups of Rembrandt paintings assembled in America in a generation. While the main focus of the show will be on the artist and his remarkable development as a painter, attention will also be given to his influence on other artists, his status as an icon, and America’s relationship to his art. Taken as a whole, the Rembrandts in America have a distinctive character: the overwhelming majority are in portrait format whether they are portraits or not. The MIA’s own Lucretia, a single-figure half-length, is a prime example.
The paintings will be a placed in groups that attempt to illuminate specific issues, such as Rembrandt’s experimentation with different ways of handling paint, his interest in actual portraiture and in various types of fantasy portraiture, and the issue of defining the boundaries of his art. While this exhibition cannot be viewed as a full-scale retrospective, it will provide visitors the rare opportunity to observe Rembrandt’s evolution from brash young artist, to confident master, to resolute observer of timeless humanity. Rembrandt collecting has always been a challenging field. The works can be difficult and expensive to obtain, and questions of authenticity are ever present. American collectors—and they are not alone in this—have often bought paintings thinking that they were getting Rembrandts only to find out later that they were the product of other hands. For this reason, a number of works formerly attributed to Rembrandt will be displayed, including one or two for which the pendulum of scholarly opinion has swung back and forth. We hope to use this opportunity to suggest answers to the all too obvious but usually evaded question: If Rembrandt is such a genius, why is it so difficult to tell which paintings are his?
The exhibit

exhibition_title: Basins, Baskets, and Bowls: Women Explore the Vessel
exhibition_description: This exhibition brings together works by modern and contemporary female artists that exhibit innovative approaches to the vessel in various media. The department of Decorative Arts, Textiles, and Sculpture conceived Basins, Baskets, and Bowls around a group of significant recent acquisitions in ceramic, fiber, and wood. These include Dark Kiva (1994) by fiber artist Mary Giles, Vessel 80 (2007) by ceramic artist Cheryl Ann Thomas, and Flanged Vessel (c. 1988) by wood artist Addie Draper. Works by modern masters such as Laura Andreson and Beatrice Wood, selected from the MIA’s collection and from private collections, are also showcased.

exhibition_department: Art of Africa and the Americas
exhibition_title: Masks from the West-African Dan People
exhibition_description:
Masks are the most important art form of the Dan, who live on either side of the border between Liberia and Côte d'Ivoire. This installation includes about 10 masks, from the MIA and from two local collectors. The exhibition's purpose is twofold: to show the variety of forms of Dan masks, and to highlight the diversity of their functions.
This exhibition is the first one of a series of small-scale experimental installations that will inform the redesign of the African galleries and will incorporate technological innovations.

exhibition_title: Cover Story: Master Bookbindings from the Collection
exhibition_description: A beautiful display of decorative bindings by noted French, Belgian, English, and American artists and designers. Most are from the golden age of fine binding, 1920–1960, but with John Graham’s sensational cover for Picasso’s illustrated edition of Balzac’s Chef d’oeuvre inconnu we see the shift to a new era exemplified by the work of Anselm Kiefer and Jim Dine.

exhibition_title: Robert Bergman: Portraits, 1986-1995
Beware Her Wiles: Woman as Temptress in the Renaissance Tradition
exhibition_description: Women will discover how to keep their men in line, and gentlemen will realize that regardless of their strengths, they are inevitably outmatched. Let the great women of old—Judith, Delilah, Salome, and their sisters—teach you a thing or two about the Power of Women.

exhibition_title: Embarrassment of Riches: Picturing Global Wealth, 2000-2010
exhibition_description:
Embarrassment of Riches explores how contemporary media artists have depicted wealth over the last ten years and upends the usual attention given to images of poverty. Following a decade of unprecedented historical fluctuations of wealth on a global scale, this exhibition is not a celebration of affluence and consumerism but an examination of the societal effects of prosperity. 
Photographers have long sought to document the effects of the economy, focusing their cameras almost exclusively on the plight of the poor and the socially disadvantaged. Most famous is Lewis Hine’s documentation of child laborers at the beginning of the 20th century and the Farm Security Administration’s survey of the migrant and rural poor during the Great Depression.
 
The exhibition addresses prosperity through three major themes—Currencies; Space; and Rituals and Style. Photographers Jacqueline Hassink (Dutch) and Alec Soth (American) document the private spaces of haute couture. Cindy Sherman (American) impersonates the patrons who support her work and the art world, and Alex Prager (American) stages the Hollywood poses of a generation influenced by cinema style. Artists Eve Sussman (American), Martin Parr (British), and Tina Barney (American) examine social rituals in Los Angeles, Europe, and the Middle East. Abelardo Morell (Cuban) reveals the speculative nature of value and the sheer quantity of goods that circulate within society. Luc Delahaye (French) investigates Davos and the behind-the-scenes financiers and politicians who fund commerce. Sze Tsung Leong (Chinese) and Robert Polidori (Canadian) document the transformation of China and other emerging countries.

exhibition_title: Nordic Modern
The Voided: Eun-Kyung Suh
exhibition_description:
The fine and tenacious threads that represent generational and societal memory are the foundation for the work of this Minnesota artist.
Bojagi, a traditional Korean art form, inspires eun-Kyung Suh’s work. Bojagi are cloths wrapped around objects for protection and transport. Although these were made out of small scraps of material, woman would decorate them to create beautifully patch-worked wrappers. Suh uses this technique to protect memories and experiences. Her installations are comprised of multiple pieces, delicate packages containing small bits of intangible information in sheer cloth. Often the packages are silk-screened with images and text, offering clues to the interior. Others, as in Purple on Thursday, hold wishes in gauzy chiffon fortune cookies.

exhibition_title: Kuon (Eternal Flow of Time): Mayumi Amada
exhibition_description:
The fine and tenacious threads that represent generational and societal memory are the foundation for the work of this Minnesota artist.
Mayumi Amada’s exhibition “Kuon: Eternal Flow of Time” focuses on domestic and feminine roles, including and the role woman play in creating continuity and home. Using lacework as a basis for an exploration of Kuon (the Japanese word for the Buddhist concept of time) the elaborate patterns she creates out of single strands represent the circles and patterns of life. Amada’s delicate forms emerge from garbage bags and water bottles often inscribed messages such as “Everybody Dies” in crisp sampler-styles lettering. Her meditations on mortality, ancestry and craft ponder, often humorously, the mundane both in life’s daily chores and in the materials around us.

exhibition_title: Matisse e Michelangelo. La seduzione della forma
The Experimental Print: Stanley William Hayter and Artists of Atelier 17
exhibition_description: Hayter’s Atelier 17 was seminal for the adventurous printmaking of the mid-20th century. He encouraged artists to try their hand at printmaking, and the studio became a meeting place for the exchange of artistic ideas. Hayter’s stimulus was particularly widespread, for Atelier 17’s 60-year run in Paris (1927 to 1988) was interrupted by a ten-year exile in New York during the 1940s. Moreover, Atelier 17 became a prototype for the collaborative workshops that have played a central role in printmaking over the past several decades. Dennis Jon has selected this presentation of innovative prints by European and American artists who worked with Hayter. The roll includes familiar names, such as Miró, Masson, Arp, Chagall, Lasansky, Nevelson, Nicholson, De Kooning, and Pollock. Others, such as André Racz and Leo Katz will be new to most of our visitors.

exhibition_title: New Pictures 3: James Welling, Glass House
exhibition_description: New Pictures 3 will feature James Welling's innovative photographs of Philip Johnson's modernist architectural masterpiece, Glass House (1949), as well as other select works that explore the refraction of light. Welling, a Professor of Photography at the University of California, Los Angeles, uses colored filters to capture the luminous effects of Johnson's glass-skinned house during different times and changing lighting conditions. New Pictures 3 will be on view from August 19, 2010 through April 10, 2011. Welling will also be the featured speaker for the Arnold Newman Annual Lecture on Photography on October 14, 2010.

exhibition_title: Chairevolution! 300 Years of Designing the Chair
exhibition_description: What do we mean when we say “good design”? Do we know it when we see it? When we sit on it? This exhibition takes a look at the meaning of good design though the examination of just one form over the course of more than 300 years – the chair. From the basic Tudor to Phillippe Starck’s Louis Ghost Armchair for Kartell, we will explore in just twenty-one chairs how designers over time have reconciled the desire for design with the basic need to find a place to sit. This exhibition is held in conjunction with the Minneapolis Institute of Arts 2010 Antiques and Design Fair, September 24-26, at the St. Paul Armory.

exhibition_title: Wide-Eyed: Panoramic Photographs
exhibition_description:
The word “panorama” was coined in the late eighteenth century by the Irish artist Robert Barker to describe his own elongated paintings.  Shortly after the invention of photography, in 1839, its practitioners also embraced the format, first making multiple-part pictures and, later on, individual images created with a succession of panoramic cameras. Most panoramic photographs fall into two categories; either they mimic normal human vision, or they extend it. Panoramas that mimic our vision are those that present a wider (or taller) view of a scene in a straightforward manner—one that an individual could take in on his or her own, by merely moving one’s head.  Panoramic photographs that extend our vision are those that show us something we cannot actually see on our own.  They extend not so much our vision of the world, but our comprehension of it, by stopping time, showing multiple views of a subject, or other results that only a camera can achieve.
The exhibition will comprise about thirty-five photographs, books by Josef Sudek and Edward Ruscha, one installation piece by Ken Fandell, and a coffee can reproducing a landscape by Ansel Adams.  Among the photographers represented are Berenice Abbott, Oscar Bailey, Frederick H. Evans, Christopher Faust, Gus Foster, Mark Klett, Stuart D. Klipper, O. G. Rejlander, Art Sinsabaugh, Todd Webb, and Jonathan Wells.  The photographs will range in time from 1848 (a daguerreotype) to within the last few years (digital color prints).

exhibition_title: Inventing the Modern World: Decorative Arts at the World's Fair 1851-1939
Flourish: Jennifer Davis, Erika Olson Gross, Terrence Payne and Joe Sinness
exhibition_description:
Each individual has their own story, but these stories are made unique by our surroundings both natural and man-made and by the burden of what we hide and what we hope to present. Jennifer Davis, Erika Olson, Terrance Payne, and Joe Sinness create work that focuses on self-image and the desire to create order where nature would have it otherwise. 
Davis’s paintings pick up where her subjects trails of thought drop off. The pastel images create a surface veneer of innocence and charm that hints at darker truths beneath the surface. Olson’s drawings and sculptures question the human impulse to clean up and arrange nature and their need to immortalize once-living objects. Payne’s oil pastels use narrative elements and line and color to capture awkward moments in life’s pursuits. Sinness uses colored pencil and sculpture is a personal examination of queer domesticity using fable, history and unconfined possibility as visual metaphor.

exhibition_title: Bad to the Bone: Prints from the Grip of Death
exhibition_description:
Death has a lot on his calendar. Of course, there is the work of ministering to and menacing his endless stream of more or less willing clients. But, he also has parties to attend, concerts to perform, and places to go. He is an athlete, adept at riding horses, driving chariots, and maneuvering other contraptions that most of us know little about. His musical skills include stringed instruments, percussion, and brass. It comes as no surprise that he is also a gifted dancer. Death also has a practical side, as demonstrated by his mastery of agricultural implements and time pieces. He is unimpeachably democratic in his associations. In fact, it is difficult to think of anyone he would avoid. Many have claimed the title of “The Great Equalizer,” but ever-busy Death retains the crown.
So compelling is Death that he has been a subject of fascination to artists since the Middle Ages. This exhibition, a complement to “The Mourners: Tomb Sculptures from the Court of Burgundy” (January 23—April 17, 2011), features the flip-side of the human act of mourning as seen by artists ranging from Renaissance master Hans Holbein to Mexican surrealist Rufino Tomayo. Some artists take delight in the dark humor of the netherworld, some shock us with its fearsome aggression, and others find poignancy in its comfort. Some remind us that Death is an unexpected visitor for whom we must prepare; while, others see Death approaching quickly, attracted by our actions.
Despite his busy calendar, Death beckons you. Great artists urge you to accept his invitation—in your imagination for the present—for eventually Death is sure to find you.

exhibition_title: From Press to Page: Book Arts in Minnesota
exhibition_description:
This exhibition highlights the creativity and craftsmanship of some of Minnesota's leading contemporary book artists and fine presses. 
Minnesota enjoys a national reputation as a locus for the book arts. Indeed, the metropolitan area of Minneapolis and St. Paul is frequently ranked behind only New York as a hotbed of book arts activity. The Minnesota book arts community--made up of artists, illustrators, designers, typographers, writers, printers, binders, papermakers, educators, collectors, and independent presses--is remarkable for its vitality, innovation, achievement, and public and private support. 
The featured selection includes books by such prominent figures as Harriet Bart, Robert Bly, Philip Gallo, Fred Hagstrom, Patricia Hampl, Bill Holm, Frank Kacmarcik, Allan Kornblum, Paulette Myers-Rich, David Rathman, Tom Rose, Gaylord Schanilec, Chip Shilling, Jody Williams, and Emerson G. Wulling.
