exhibition_title: Heroic Africans: Legendary Leaders, Iconic Sculptures
Shapeshifting: Transformations in Native American Art
Facing the Lens: Portraits of Photographers
exhibition_description:
Photographers, naturally, have a unique relationship with the camera, given it is their tool of choice. They are accustomed to being behind it, shooting with it, and seeing the results of their efforts. Many photographers are also comfortable situating themselves in front of their lenses, making self portraiture either an aspect of their work or its mainstay. On the other hand, some are notoriously camera shy, allowing few photographic images of themselves--Henri Cartier-Bresson being among the most notable.
Portraiture is one of the oldest, enduring, and constant genres of image making, in all media. In the early decades of photography, humans made up the vast majority of subjects placed before the camera, because people believed whole-heartedly in the verisimilitude of the medium. Since photographs were taken “from nature” and did not involve the hand of the artist, they were thought to perfectly depict the physical--and sometimes even spiritual--characteristics of the sitter. Today, we know this to not necessarily be the case, and as photographers continue to confront the camera face on, the lens happily offers up photographic half truths and “lies.”
This exhibition features about 75 pieces, drawn largely from the MIA’s permanent collection, dating from the 1850s to within the last decade. There are both self-portraits and images by other makers. The eye of the photographer is examined as a metaphor for seeing and the act of photographing and cameras are suggested as an extension of the photographer’s eye. In this vein, images are included of Brassai, Bill Brandt, Man Ray, and Robert Mapplethorpe.
The idea that a single, solitary photographic image of an individual can fully represent its subject is, of course, spurious. Multiple images, therefore, can fill in the blanks and give a more rounded impression of the sitter, as demonstrated by many acute photographers. Eadweard Muybridge included sequential, full-figure profile images of himself in his mammoth 1880s project on human motion, in which he

exhibition_title: Hot House: Flowers for after the Frost
exhibition_description: On view from the Equinox nearly until the Solstice, this floral free-for-all will include works from every department in the museum. As in any greenhouse, we can expect harmony and discord... abundant brilliant blossoms and a few that faltered. From Redouté to Warhol, Mondriaan [That’s no typo—he used two A’s in his early days] to Mapplethorpe, this will be a mixed bouquet. Tom Rassieur is not known for his green thumb, but he’s going to turn up the heat and hope for the best.

exhibition_title: Venice on Paper
exhibition_description: As a maritime power at the heart of international trade and travel, Venice has been an important cultural center since the Middle Ages, inspiring both native and visiting artists to create exceptional and unprecedented works of art. Described as the "Queen of the Adriatic" with its maze of canals and confluence of Byzantine, Arab, and European architecture, Venice has also been a favorite subject for artists as they have strived to capture the city's unique character and beauty. From Renaissance woodcuts designed by Titian to Venetian views by Canaletto and Whistler, "Venice on Paper" explores the city through the graphic arts, bringing together five centuries of original prints, drawings, books, and photographs, all made in or about this enchanting "floating" city.

exhibition_title: Saints and Sinners: Women in Renaissance Prints
exhibition_description:
Women in the Bible and in legends about saints were depicted frequently in Renaissance art to portray contemporary ideas about the ideal woman, almost invariably by male artists. In this exhibition, 22 prints are examined from a feminist perspective, stressing the woman’s subservient role in 15th and 16th century Europe, but also the negative perception of women as immoral temptresses. In some examples, the overt moralistic message is tempered with erotic overtones. 
The works in this exhibition were made by Italian, German, French, Dutch and Flemish artists at a time when printmaking became a common art form. The profusion of religious prints and reproductions by copyists enabled the wide dissemination of images that supplemented the religious education and personal devotion of the viewer, while also upholding strict gender roles.

exhibition_title: The Genius of Martin Schongauer: The Engravings
exhibition_description: This exhibition features twenty-two engravings by Martin Schongauer (about 1450–1490), the most influential German artist of the fifteenth century. Drawn from the museum’s permanent collection, this selection of rare prints demonstrates the exceptional quality, innovative technique, and renowned refinement of Schongauer’s work.

exhibition_title: Visions of Piety: Devotional Prints in the Counter-Reformation
exhibition_description: This focused exhibition of prints examines the dramatic religious imagery produced in Catholic Europe in this period, and the power of print to foster private devotion and promote tenets of the Church.

exhibition_title: Wild Things
exhibition_description: Satyrs—half man, half goat. Centaurs—half man, half horse. Tritons—half-man, half-fish. They and their female counterparts are known to cavort in the woods and wreak havoc on the seas. Yet they also have their civilized side—raising families, attending parties, playing music, worshiping, and even providing artistic inspiration. So, in the interest of survival, we survey images of composite creatures from the Renaissance, the Baroque, and the Rococo eras of art.

exhibition_title: William Blake: Illustrations of The Book of Job
exhibition_description:
The British visionary poet, painter, illustrator, and engraver William Blake (1757-1827) was one of the leading figures of the Romantic era. Illustrations of The Book of Job, first published in London in 1825, ranks among Blake's best-known and most enduring achievements. This masterwork of the engraver's art comprises 21 line engravings and an engraved title page; each plate is accompanied by text that Blake selected from Job and other books of the Bible.
The Book of Job, one of the books of the Hebrew Bible (Old Testament), recounts the trials and eventual spiritual awakening of Job, a virtuous and wealthy citizen of Uz. The biblical text was written as a didactic poem framed by a prose prologue and epilogue. Intended as a challenge to the belief that misfortunes are punishment for sin, The Book of Job was for Blake the apotheosis of lyric expression.
Taken as a whole, Blake's engravings are a metaphysical commentary in the form of a symbolic narrative. By Blake's own account, the engravings are not to be read literally, but are rather to be spiritually discerned as conceptions of the artist's personal reading of the Bible. To Blake, Job's spiritual journey paralleled his own creative struggles and spiritual awareness. Completed when the artist was nearly 70 years of age, Illustrations of the Book of Job is the last of Blake's experiments in combining text and image.

exhibition_title: L’Ancien Régime: Life at the French Court in the 17th and 18th Centuries
exhibition_description:
The glittering society of Versailles was a popular subject in prints in 17th and 18th-century France. For the estimated 1,000 courtiers who kept rooms at the chateau, a dizzying schedule of amusements was offered each season—fêtes, masquerade balls, outdoor theater performances and concerts, fireworks displays—with no expense spared. Arranging these entertainments and parties was important business, overseen by an official bureaucratic department of the king’s household—called the Menus Plaisirs du Roi—which employed a small army of artists, architects, and craftsmen to execute the elaborate undertakings. 

The prints in this show, drawn from the permanent collection although many never before exhibited in the museum, capture the splendor of the Ancien Régime—or “Old Regime” as post-Revolutionary France termed the former system of aristocratic rule. Many of the printmakers, Charles Nicolas Cochin II, Jean-Michel Moreau, Jean Le Pautre, were commissioned by the kings to commemorate the most important of these celebrations and fêtes, with a desire to propagate, both at home and abroad, the grandeur of their reigns. Ironically, these widely disseminated images of the frivolity and decadence of courtly life may also have fostered mounting tensions against the royal regime, helping to turn the oppressive system on its head at the end of the 18th century.

exhibition_title: From Rembrandt to Matisse: Selected Works on Paper
exhibition_description: This exhibition presents more than 60 outstanding European and American prints and drawings, from the seventeenth to the twentieth century, featuring works by Rembrandt, Goya, Pissarro, Denis, and Matisse. Drawn primarily from the MIA’s permanent collection, the selection will highlight recent acquisitions and important loans.

exhibition_title: From Dürer to Picasso: Selections from the Department of Prints and Drawings
Sir Francis Seymour Haden: Physician and Printmaker
exhibition_description:
During his lifetime, Sir Francis Seymour Haden (1818-1910) was better known as a surgeon than as an artist. It was considered proper for a 19th century English gentleman to learn how to draw and to collect art, but more as an avocation than as a profession. Haden pursued his medical training in London and Paris and eventually came to specialize in obstetrics. His private practice was successful enough to allow him to acquire a significant collection of old master prints, a well-appointed London home, and a country manor house, and to travel frequently throughout England and the rest of Europe. It was during these holidays that Haden turned to etching and to his favorite subject, the landscape and the eternal beauty of nature. 
While a medical student at the Sorbonne in Paris, Haden took night classes in anatomical drawing at the École des Beaux-Arts "to train his powers of observation" and to improve his surgical skills. In 1844, on a trip though Italy, he etched his first copper plate. Haden returned to the medium in 1857, and, because he was convinced that etching was an art form equal to painting, he founded the Royal society of Painter-Etchers. He also authored several art books including The Etched Work of Rembrandt (1879) and was knighted for his artistic accomplishments by Queen Victoria in 1894.
Despite the vital role he played in the graphic arts, Haden never considered himself a professional artist. He was an amateur in the best sense of the work, and left behind an important legacy of etched works and writings. The 31 Haden prints in this exhibition were selected from more than 250 of his etchings, drypoints, and mezzotints held in the Department of Prints and Drawings at the Minneapolis Institute of Arts.

exhibition_title: Metamorphosis: Maria Sibylla Merian's Insects of Suriname
exhibition_description: In 1699, Maria Sibylla Merian (1647-1717) sailed to Suriname to draw and study the insects of the rain forest. She was particularly fascinated by the transformation of caterpillars into butterflies and moths, and her images reveal their successive stages of development from egg, to caterpillar and pupa, and finally to mature adult. The book that resulted from her two year study, Metamorphosis insectorum Surinamensium (Transformation of Suriname insects), included ninety studies of insects, most drawn life-size. Merian was a pioneer in a long line of women botanical artists and the first to depict insects in relation to their host plants. This exhibition will feature nearly twenty of Merian’s images of Suriname selected from the permanent collection.

exhibition_title: On the Same Page: Artist's Books New to the Collection
exhibition_description:
Artist’s books emerged as an art form in the late nineteenth century, and have since become repositories for unbounded artistic imagination. The chance to interpret a favorite text with their own vision is, for many artists, irresistible. The artist’s books exhibited here—spanning more than a century—display a unique commingling of words and picture on the same page, from Pierre Bonnard’s exquisitely daring Parallèlement to Donald Baechler’s quizzical Double Whammy. 
The Minneapolis Institute of Arts is committed to continually strengthening its collection of artist’s books, now numbering more than 600 works housed in the Department of Prints and Drawings. This exhibition presents a selection of recent and important additions to the permanent collection. As these books demonstrate, Greek poetry can provoke an artist’s imagination as readily as a modern-day fairy tale. The artist and author may be friends—like Sonia Delaunay and Jacques Damase—or the artist may take on the dual role of author and illustrator, as Hans Arp and Mark Beard do here.
Exciting, experimental, unexpected—the artist’s book format signifies, above all, collaboration between publisher and printer, image and text, high art and craft. The possibilities for expression ensure that all will persist in meeting on the same page for a long time to come.

exhibition_title: Edward Ruscha: Stains
exhibition_description:
One of the most innovative and influential artists to emerge in the 1960s, veteran Los Angeles painter Ed Ruscha is internationally known for his irreverent and often ironic depictions of Southern California culture, architecture, and urban environment. A first-generation Pop artist who explored meaning in the objects and circumstances of everyday life, Ruscha consistently established a strong conceptual framework for his art. His life-long fascination with words and language—especially the intersection of the visual and verbal—continues to infuse his work to the present day.
Ruscha’s Stains portfolio, produced and published by the artist in 1969, features a series of 75 sheets of white paper, each bearing a single stain from one of a spectrum of common organic materials, including such household products as Vasoline petroleum jelly, tincture merthiolate, and Liquid Drano; food items such as egg yolk, red wine (Chateau Latour 1962), and Hershey’s chocolate syrup; bodily fluids including urine and semen; and such oddities as rose petal (American Beauty) and “ant.” The portfolio is housed in a simple black clamshell case, the interior of which has been marked with one additional stain—the blood of the artist.

exhibition_title: The Pose of Poetry and Prose: Aristide Maillol Interprets the Artist's Book
exhibition_description: French sculptor Aristide Maillol (1861-1944) extended his modeling genius to the art of book illustration. This exhibition, drawn entirely from the museum's permanent collection, features a nearly complete survey of Maillol's artist's book oeuvre, with texts ranging from Virgil to Paul Verlaine.

exhibition_title: Pablo Picasso: Livres d'Artistes
exhibition_description: Internationally celebrated as a painter and sculptor, Pablo Picasso (1881-1973) was also an innovative and prolific printmaker and book artist. His extensive graphic oeuvre includes more than twenty-five livres d’artistes, deluxe limited edition illustrated books featuring original prints. Drawn entirely from the MIA’s permanent collection, this exhibition showcases a selection of more than a dozen of Picasso’s livres d’artistes, with texts ranging from Buffon to Tzara.

exhibition_title: Breaking with Convention: Avant-garde Artist's Books
Extraordinary Editions: Artist's Books of the 20th Century, Part I and II
exhibition_description: This two-part exhibition presents a selection of outstanding twentieth-century artist’s books drawn from the MIA’s permanent collection. The works on display embody unparalleled artistic achievement among the many modern and contemporary artists who were and are active in the book arts including Hans Arp, Fernand Leger, Max Ernst, Man Ray, Matisse, Picasso to name only a few.

exhibition_title: Marks of Intention: Abstract Art on Paper 1945-2005
exhibition_description: This installation features a selection of more than fifty drawings, prints, and artists’ books that demonstrates the persistent interest in abstraction and non-objective art among modern and contemporary artists working in the postwar era. The works on view were drawn entirely from the museum’s permanent collection and range from Jackson Pollack’s rare early experimental etchings to Robert Motherwell’s dynamic gestural color prints to Brice Marden’s monochromatic minimalist abstractions. The installation includes examples by Willem de Kooning, Grace Hartigan, Helen Frankenthaler, Philip Guston, Joan Mitchell, Cy Twombly, Beauford Delaney, Richard Diebenkorn, Louise Bourgeois, Sam Francis, John Newman, Mel Kendrick, Julie Mehretu, and others.

exhibition_title: The 1960s: Prints and Editions
exhibition_description: 45 original prints and edited artist’s books by many of the decade’s foremost artists are drawn from the MIA’s permanent collection.

exhibition_title: From Life: Figural Art on Paper, 1980-2006
exhibition_description: This exhibition of prints, drawings, and artist’s books explores some of the many artistic approaches and ideas of contemporary artists employed in the depiction of the human form. The present selection, featuring work by more than thirty-five contemporary artists, includes recent acquisitions not previously exhibited in the MIA’s galleries.

exhibition_title: Space/Surface: Contemporary Sculptors as Printmakers
exhibition_description: Contemporary artists have long embraced a multi-disciplinary approach in their artistic practice. This exhibition showcases editioned prints by more than twenty leading sculptors, including works by Richard Serra, Louise Bourgeois, Lee Bontecou, Ellsworth Kelly, Frank Stella, Sol LeWitt, Donald Judd, Joel Shapiro, Kiki Smith, and Martin Puryear.

exhibition_title: Shaping Reality: Geometric Abstraction after 1960
Wordscapes: Text as Image in Contemporary Art
From Frankenthaler to Freud: Master Contemporary Prints from the Permanent Collection
exhibition_description: From its founding as the Institute's first curatorial department in 1916, the Department of Prints and Drawings has actively acquired outstanding examples of contemporary graphic art for its permanent collection. This exhibition features a selection of more than 50 prints, monotypes, and multiples by leading American and European artists of the second half of the 20th-century, including Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns, Helen Frankenthaler, Cy Twombly, Robert Motherwell, Chuck Close, Joan Mitchell, Jim Dine, Ed Ruscha, Joseph Beuys, David Hockney, Georg Baselitz, Susan Rothenberg, Yvonne Jacquette, Lucien Freud, Vija Celmins, Elizabeth Murray, Anselm Kiefer, Kiki Smith, Leslie Dill, Lorna Simpson and others.

exhibition_title: The Artful Animal: 500 Years of Beasts, Birds, and Other Earthly Creatures
exhibition_description: Drawn primarily from the MIA’s permanent collection, this inter-departmental exhibition examined the theme of the animal in art from the 16th century to the present. Approximately 80 prints, drawings, watercolors, paintings, sculptures, books, and decorative objects, which depict mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, fish, insects, and imaginary creatures, were featured.

exhibition_title: Twelve American Artists: Prints, Drawings, Oils
Pop on Paper
Contemporary Art on Paper, 1990-2000
Matisse / Jazz
Copper Into Gold: The Etchings and Drypoints of James McNeill Whistler
Vermillion Editions, Ltd. - Part II
American Artists' Books: 1967-2004 from the Collection of The Minneapolis Institute of Arts
Ed Ruscha
Rembrandt as Printmaker
exhibition_description: The present installation is a survey of Rembrandt's activities as a printmaker, with selected works from the Institute's holdings of 156 Rembrandt prints.

exhibition_title: The Nabis
exhibition_description: In 1889, a group of young artists banded together in Paris and called themselves the Nabis, from the Hebrew word for “prophets.” Included in this group were Pierre Bonnard, Edouard Vuillard, Paul Ranson, Paul Sérusier, Maurice Denis, Félix Vallotton, Ker-Xavier Roussel, and Aristide Maillol. They sought to integrate art with life and move beyond what they perceived as the limits of Impressionism. Although the Nabis were trained as painters, they applied their talents to decorative objects and home interiors, theater design and programs, book and magazine illustration, as well as posters and prints. This installation highlighted a selection of their graphic works culled from the permanent collection.

exhibition_title: A Vision of Paris: Etchings of Charles Meryon
exhibition_description: The etchings of Charles Meryon (1821-1879) reveal a vision of Paris before the changes put into effect during the rule of Napoleon III's Second Empire. Meryon's prints capture the essence of the medieval sections of town that were being torn down to accommodate the wide boulevards and new parks and squares of the Emperor's master plan. Yet, Meryon's etchings are not simply exact renditions of vanishing structures, but a personal vision of a city he loved. This vision was darkened by a severe mental illness which eventually took the artist's life just as his etchings were receiving serious attention and favorable reviews. Meryon's legacy of beautifully executed etchings continues to fascinate viewers, and he is considered on of the most gifted printmakers of all time.

exhibition_title: At the Water's Edge: 19th-Century Prints from the Jones Collection
exhibition_description: This installation will survey the way water provided powerful inspiration to a variety of gifted 19th-century artists. From the canals of Venice to the busy rivers of the Thames and the Seine, from sailing ships to fishing boats, water proved an irresistible subject in the works of James McNeill Whistler, Francis Seymour Haden, D.Y. Cameron and others.

exhibition_title: The Prints of Francisco Goya
Albrecht Dürer and the Prints of the Danube School
exhibition_description: This exhibition highlighted the artists of the Danube School who lived and worked by the Danube River from Regensburg to Vienna in the early 16th-century. The prints of the Danube School are characterized by a profound sensitivity to nature. Landscape and atmospheric elements were used to an unprecedented degree to emphasize subject and mood, while the structure of growing, organic things governed the compositions. It was the Danube School which first introduced into Western Art the idea that pure landscape was a subject worthy of representation. Artists highlighted in the exhibition included Albrecht Dürer, Albrecht Altdorfer, Lucas Cranach, and Augustin Hirchvogel.

exhibition_title: Old Master Prints from the Permanent Collection
exhibition_description: This exhibition contains approximately 25 masterpieces created before 1600 from the Department of Prints and Drawings. The majority of the works have been added to the collection since 1985 and showcase the beauty of European printmaking of the 15th and 16th centuries.

exhibition_title: Monsters and Mayhem: Renaissance Prints from the Jones Collection
exhibition_description: This installation takes an unusual look at 15th century prints devoted to real and imagined beasts, fierce battles, bawdy mischief makers, and general bad behavior of the worst kind. It will feature works by many of the most important artists of the period including Andrea Mantegna, Israhel van Meckenem, Albrecht Dürer, and Martin Schongauer.

exhibition_title: Käthe Kollwitz: Prints with a Purpose
Flemish Fantasia: Invention and Imagination in Sixteenth Century Flemish Engravings
exhibition_description: Mannerism, a refined artistic style originating in Italy, took hold in Flanders in the 16th century, bringing with it a new repertoire of subjects, techniques, and sensibilities. It coincided with the rapid development of printmaking, especially engraving, by Flemish artists. Master engravers such as Pieter Breugel the Elder and Hendrick Goltzius transformed the role of prints from being mere book illustrations to works of art in their own right, avidly collected by the newly prosperous merchant class.

exhibition_title: The Painted Page
The Book of Hours
exhibition_description: Gallery 344 will host a presentation of Books of Hours from the Institute's permanent collection produced in Flanders in the late 15th and early 16th centuries. A Book of Hours is a lay person's prayer book read during private devotions. These books were small enough to be held in the hand, and were easily portable. Many of the pages in these laboriously hand-written books were illuminated - literally "lighted up" - with miniature scenes and elaborate initials, painted in bright colors and gilded with gold and precious metals. Preserved in closed volumes for centuries, illuminated manuscripts remain fresh and vivid examples of medieval artistic techniques.

exhibition_title: Old Master Drawings: Steps in Artistic Creation
Surreal Objects
Global Positioning c. 1600: A Rare World Map
exhibition_description: The Ricci Map is the first map in Chinese to show the Americas, and the first printed map to incorporate both Eastern and Western cartography. This large scale map, 12 1/5 ft x 5 ½ ft, was created in 1602 by a visiting Italian-born Jesuit priest, Matteo Ricci, and thought to be commissioned by the court of Emperor Wanli. This is the first time the map is on display in North America. The Ricci Map will be shown at the Library of Congress in Washington DC (January 12 – April 10, 2010) and the Minneapolis Institute of Arts (May 15 – August 29, 2010).

exhibition_title: Drawings for the New Century
exhibition_description:
The Minneapolis Institute of Arts has actively collected drawings for nearly a century, acquiring works of outstanding quality by many of the world’s most prominent artists. Expanding on this curatorial imperative, the Department of Prints and Drawings has in recent years redoubled its efforts to collect important contemporary drawings by both established and emerging artists. 
This exhibition presents a selection of sixteen drawings produced during the past decade, including a number of key recent acquisitions. Highlights include a monumental three-panel color pencil drawing by Iranian-American artist Siah Armajani made in response to the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina; innovative figurative works by Mequitta Ahuja, Nicola Hicks, Stacey Davidson, and Cynthia Lin; and masterly drawings by Christopher Cook, Charles Gaines, and May Stevens.
Complementing the selection are several drawings on loan from local private collections, including a dazzling large-format pastel abstraction by Irish-American artist Sean Scully, an intricate silver pencil drawing on black paper by Lee Bonticou, and a delicate figure drawing by Chloe Piene.

exhibition_title: American Indian gallery reinstallation
Painting Before and After Words: Margaret Wall-Romana
exhibition_description: Margaret Wall-Romana’s work engages with the traditions of oil painting. She controls the physics of paint, but also lets go of that control to open up to the paint’s own properties. The irresistible tensions on the surfaces of her large-scale paintings keep viewers looking. Wall-Romana structures her paintings using an elaborate atmospheric perspective balanced with non-illusionistic color. A sharp student of art history, she conflates the still-life delicacies of the Dutch Golden Age with Mannerist attitudes towards scale, Hudson River School atmospherics, and yolky Abstract Expressionist smears. Formally, she pushes the physical properties of paint to their limit, with her use of thin, translucent colors to create delicate surfaces, and chalky impasto for ripe forms and textures.

exhibition_title: Ground Truth: Peter Happel Christian
exhibition_description: The scientific method is a process for documenting events, creating knowledge, and testing theories. Peter Happel Christian measures, collects information, and records data, creating sculptures and photographs that are positioned at the intersection of art, science, and history. He observes the technologies that mediate our everyday relationship with art and natural phenomena, including geography, cartography, and topographical surveys. As part of his MAEP exhibition, “Ground Truth,” Happel Christian has invited MIA staff to collaborate with him. He has asked to borrow their office plants, which he will then install in the MAEP galleries and care for during the show.

exhibition_title: Beauty and Power: Renaissance and Baroque Bronzes from the Peter Marino Collection
exhibition_description:
Over the course of more than two decades, the well-known New York architect Peter Marino has formed an exemplary collection of highly important Italian and French bronze sculptures of the Renaissance and the Baroque. This exhibition features approximately 30 of his European bronze sculptures from the golden age of this artistic genre. The bronzes in the exhibition provide an overview of the development of the collectible small bronze in the Renaissance and the Baroque with examples of stellar quality. 
The exhibition will be on view at The Wallace Collection, London (April 29 – July 25, 2010); The Huntington Library, Museum and Botanical Gardens, San Marino, California (October 9, 2010 – January 24, 2011) and the Minneapolis Institute of Arts (February 5 – May 15, 2011).

exhibition_title: New Pictures 4: Evidence by Angela Strassheim
exhibition_description: Evidence features photographs that bring together Strassheim’s forensic photography training with her long-standing investigation of the dark undercurrents of American domestic life.

exhibition_title: Midnight Party
Goshka Macuga: It Broke From Within
Homecoming: The Art Collection of James J. Hill

venues.venue: Minnesota Historical Society - James J. Hill House

exhibition_title: Magnifying Nature: 1960s Printed Textiles
exhibition_description: In the 1960s, top textile design firms such as Heal’s of England and Marimekko of Finland sold the most daring, lively and trend-setting patterns produced during the decade. Designers Lucienne Day, Howard Carter, Maija Isola and Marjatta Metsovaara abstracted motifs from the natural world in their bold graphic designs, and employed energetic colors that infused youthful energy. Magnifying Nature explores these gigantic patterns through a selection of screen-printed textiles from the MIA’s collection and examples of clothing from the Goldstein Museum of Design at the University of Minnesota.

exhibition_title: Art of the Native Americans: The Thaw Collection
The Mourners: Tomb Sculptures from the Court of Burgundy
Foot in the Door 4
Lost Wax, Found Sculpture
Collateral Damage: Scenes from a War
exhibition_description:
This exhibition explores the tragic consequences and incalculable human cost of war and violence. For centuries, artists of various nationalities and points of view have addressed this difficult subject in their work, creating distinctive expressions ranging from virulent anti-war sentiments to frank eyewitness accounts to personal reflections on loss and grief. Drawn primarily from the MIA’s extensive collection of graphic art, the 35 works on display include some of the most compelling representations of war and violence ever created. From Francisco Goya’s renowned Disasters of War etchings to Otto Dix’s infamous Der Krieg (War) portfolio to Daniel Heyman’s powerful portraits of tortured Iraqi War prisoners, the selection shines a bright light on the ravages of war and violence as seen through the eyes and minds of artists. 
Also featured are important graphic works by Honoré Daumier, Käthe Kollwitz, Max Pechstein, Max Beckmann, George Bellows, George Grosz, Pablo Picasso, Jacob Lawrence, David Rathman, Ken Campbell, Stephen Dupont, as well as a major sculptural installation by British contemporary artists Dinos and Jake Chapman.
This exhibition was organized in conjunction with the museum-sponsored program MIA Inside/Out: Battle of Everyouth, a special one-night event presented as part of the Northern Spark Festival, a citywide celebration of experimental contemporary art in public places. This free program begins at sundown on Saturday, June 4, 2011, on the shared campus of the MIA and Minneapolis College of Art and Design.

exhibition_title: Face to Face
MCAD@MIA
A Field Guide to Snow and Ice: Paula McCartney
Ornamental Invasion: Liz Miller
Who's Afraid of Edith Carlson?
Lyonel Feininger: At the Edge of the World
Vasari, Gli Uffizi E Il Duca
Juan Gris. Rimes de la forme et de la couleur
The Experiment Continues: Design from 1945 to the Present
exhibition_description: The MIA’s Modernism collection, focusing on decorative arts and design from 1880-1940, is one of the world’s best. Taking that collection as a departure point, this exhibition brings attention to the museum’s modest but notable holdings of design from the post-World War II era to the present. American and European designers over the last six decades have explored abstraction of form, new technologies, new materials, and adventurous colors in items for household use. This exhibition focuses on these developments through over thirty examples of furniture, industrial design, jewelry, and other consumer objects, including notable recent acquisitions. Works by Americans Charles and Ray Eames, Harry Bertoia, Frank Gehry, and Michael Graves, as well as Europeans Eero Aarnio, Piero Fornasetti, and Jens Quistgaard, are among the designers included.

exhibition_title: Paris in the Twenties
Elihu Vedder: Voyage on the Nile
The Young Van Dyck at the Prado
Legacy: The Artistry of the Wyeth Family
Manet: Portraying Life
Tiziano e l'idea del paesaggio nella pittura del Cinquecento
Afro Basaldella. The American Period

venues.venue: Museo di Arte Moderna e Contemporanea di Trento e Rovereto

exhibition_title: Bodies and Shadows: Caravaggio and His Legacy

venues.venue: Los Angeles County Museum of Art

exhibition_title: Kano Sanraku and Sansetsu

exhibition_department: Chinese, Indian, and Southeast Asian Art
exhibition_title: Earth, Water, Fire
Governor's Residence: 2011-2013
Conversations with Wood: Selections from the Waterbury Collection
exhibition_description:
This exhibition showcases the premier wood art collection of Minneapolitans David and Ruth Waterbury, which is considered one of the best in the country. The Waterburys have embraced the evolution of the field and its artists for twenty-five years, collecting pieces that range from exquisitely turned bowls, to objects conceived around irregularities within the material, to works that explore imaginative ways to manipulate the medium.
The exhibition includes approximately 80 pieces of wood art, representing the changing approaches to the medium during the past twenty-five years, from simple turned vessels to sculpted and constructed works. The Waterbury collection includes works by many prominent artists in the field, both nationally and internationally, including William Hunter, Ron Kent, Michelle Holtzapfel, Robyn Horn, Robert Stocksdale, Michael Mode, Alan Stirt, Hayley Smith, and Todd Hoyer.

exhibition_title: A Connoisseur’s Cabinet: Drawings from the Joseph F. McCrindle Collection
exhibition_description:
Joseph F. McCrindle (1923–2008) was a tireless and gifted art collector, with a particular fondness for drawings. He began collecting seriously in the 1960s and never stopped, forming one of the greatest private collections of drawings in America in the 20th century. Traveling frequently to London and Italy in search of great drawings, the collection grew to a staggering 2,500 works before his death. It was not only remarkable for its size, but also its breadth and quality, guided by an exceptionally discerning eye.
Mr. McCrindle’s passion for drawings was matched by a generous spirit. Upon his death, his collection was divided up among some 30 American institutions, with the MIA acquiring a total of 98 works from his collection. Celebrating this extraordinary gift to the museum, this exhibition features selections from this rich, and very personal collection. And Mr. McCrindle’s generous legacy continues to enrich our institution. Four of the studies from his gift came to the museum in a fragile state, and they were recently conserved with a generous award from the Joseph F. McCrindle Foundation.

exhibition_title: Michael Mazur: The Inferno of Dante
The Sports Show
exhibition_description:
Photography, moving images, and new media outlets have transformed sporting events into spectacles of mass participation, pop culture, and political drama. Early, innovative photographers and filmmakers were fundamental to this transformation, creating powerful images that put millions of people in the center of the historic, athletic-action. The Sports Show spotlights the artistry and cultural significance of this shift.
Early 20th-century photographers first captured leisure sports. Jacques-Henri Lartigue’s photographs of his family’s adventures driving racecars and flying planes exemplified these private and personal endeavors. Media imagery, however, quickly moved sports into the public arena. By the 1960s, televised events radically altered the nature of sports, players’ standings, and fans’ participation. Charismatic professional athletes—Joe Namath, Muhammad Ali and others—became international pop icons, and television audiences expanded exponentially. Roger Welch’s The O.J. Simpson Project, reveals Simpson’s early attempts to shape his popular image as a non-athlete, and is seen in the exhibition for the first time in the U.S. since its 1977 premier. 
Now, in the 21st century, body-thumping music, roaming cameras, and multi-screen global broadcasts of sporting events create larger-than-life spectacles that attract the critical attention of contemporary artists. Capturing the power of these events, a centerpiece of the exhibition is Paul Pfeiffer’s The Saints, an immersive sound-and-video installation based on the 1966 World Cup final between Germany and Great Britain, which examines nationalism and crowd dynamics in sports. It was shown previously at Hamburger Bahn of in Berlin, Germany, and the Guggenheim Museum, Bilbao, Spain. The installation at the Minneapolis Institute of Arts is its U.S. premier.
The Sports Show features approximately 175 astonishing works arranged around themes such as Leisure; Circulation; Politics; Icons; Race; and Spectacle. The exhibition includes photographs by Richard A

exhibition_department: Art of Africa and the Americas
exhibition_title: Woven and Worn: Textile Arts and Silverworks of the Diné
Finally, We Are All Young Again: Adam Caillier and Michael Mott
exhibition_description: Adam Caillier and Michael Mott have worked together in the past and this is a continuation of their collaborative practice. Here, they will be making a dramatic shift in scale and orientation from a book project to a large gallery installation. Recently, Caillier and Mott have begun rereading a book of 1980’s photographs of the ballet dancer Mikhail Baryshnikov and choreographer John Butler, and they have been drawn to the relationship between architectural space, rehearsal, and the bodies of artists/dancers. As collaborators, they are proposing a one-room exhibition of projected photographs and other two-dimensional media rooted in this material.

exhibition_title: Movie: Scott Nedrelow
A Means of Escape: European Posters from 1889 to 1930
exhibition_description: Like advertisements today, the enticing images of early poster art often promote more than the featured product. They offer ways to leave your everyday existence behind and enter a world of fun, fantasy and hedonism. This exhibition examines escapism in large-scale advertisements and focuses on three forms of diversion: fast transportation, dazzling entertainment and reckless imbibing. While such activities carry an inherent appeal, an investigation of the historical context surrounding these works will also help to reveal what the public might have been trying to forget.

exhibition_title: New Pictures 5: Jason Fulford
exhibition_description:
A few years ago, a friend gave artist Jason Fulford a manila envelope, found at a flea market. The envelope contained over 80 photographs of different mushroom types, each composed and annotated with the care of someone who just had to be a mushroom collector. These anonymous photographs inspired Fulford to create his own collection of photographs, publications, sculptures, and performances, all under the umbrella of his fictional Soon Institute. Similar to the lifecycle of mushrooms, the project goes underground and periodically sprouts up in various artistic forms (including The Mushroom Collector, a book he published in 2010), in unexpected locations, such as New York, California, and Amsterdam. The “Mushroom Collector” is now rumored to be arriving this October at the Minneapolis Institute of Arts as part of “New Pictures 5,” and we are looking forward to seeing what form it will take.
John Cage, the avant-garde musician, thinker, and, of course, mushroom collector, noted in his book For the Birds (1981), “It’s useless to pretend to know mushrooms. They escape your erudition. [The more you know them] the less sure you feel about identifying them.” Fulford’s photographs draws inspiration from Cage’s pleasure, wonder, and openness in the pursuit of visual knowledge. The pictures appear to be unremarkable shots of commonplace objects, people, and places. Yet a closer look reveals humorous and subtle oddities: a crane lifting two ladders; a natural branch form casting an artificial multicolor shadow; a happy threesome running toward a cave as though part of a travel advertisement. Instead of a singular, heroic photograph, Fulford’s images reveal themselves through repetition, sequences, relationships between form and shadow, abstraction and reality. 
Fulford is the co-founder of the publishing house J&L Books in Atlanta / New York, and the author of several titles, such as Sunbird (2000), Crushed (2003), and Raising Frogs for $$$ (2006). This will be his first museum exhibition.

exhibition_title: Edo Pop: The Graphic Impact of Japanese Prints
exhibition_description:
The Minneapolis Institute of Arts is home to some 3,000 Japanese woodblock prints. These works, collectively known as ukiyo-e, or “pictures of the floating world,” were produced during Japan’s Edo period (1600-1868). Reflecting the interests and activities of the newly emerging class of moneyed commoners, ukiyo-e prints first featured the reigning beauties of the pleasure quarters and the dashing actors of the Kabuki Theater. Later, artists expanded their repertoires to include landscapes, floral studies, legendary heroes, and even ghoulish themes. Although similar exhibitions have been organized chronologically with prints by individual artists and artistic lineages grouped together, this exhibition is arranged thematically: Women of the Floating World; The Yoshiwara; Actors and the Kabuki Theater; Great Escapes (Travel Prints); Heroes and Warriors; Visual Witticisms (Mitate-e); Classical Inspirations. 
Edo Pop: The Graphic Impact of Japanese Prints showcases 188 of the Minneapolis Institute of Arts’ best prints by the genre’s greatest artists including Harunobu, Kiyonaga, Utamaro, Shunsho, Sharaku, Toyokuni, Hokusai, and Hiroshige. Collected and donated by some of the museum’s most generous donors, including Richard P. Gale and Louis W. Hill Jr., the prints comprising this exhibition are renowned for their superb preservation, breathtaking designs and colors, and astonishingly refined printing techniques. 
While the impact of Japanese woodblock prints on the French Impressionists has been well documented through exhibitions and publications, the enduring influence of this art form, even into the 21st century, has received little attention. This exhibition will demonstrate how these lively, graphic images and their urbane subjects continue to inspire contemporary artists, both in Japan and around the world. Iona Rozeal Brown, an African-American artist, sees parallels in the materialism of Japan’s “floating world” and contemporary hip-hop culture. Her portraits of young black women rendered in ukiyo-e style a

exhibition_title: Highpoint Editions—Decade One
exhibition_description:
In its first ten years, Highpoint has become a vibrant part of the Twin Cities art scene. Less well known is its national and increasingly international stature as a publisher of exquisitely made prints. "Highpoint Editions -- Decade One" celebrates their professional collaborations with fine artists of many stripes. The diversity and the quality testify to HP’s Master Printer Cole Rogers and his talented staff’s ability to work with artists to bring their visions into material form. The MIA is delighted to salute Highpoint and to present highlights from its production to a broad public audience.
Featured artists will include: Carlos Amorales, Santiago Cucullu, Rob Fischer, Adam Helms, Cameron Martin, Julie Mehretu, Clarence Morgan, Lisa Nankivil, Todd Norsten, Chloe Piene, Jessica Rankin, David Rathman, and others.

exhibition_title: The Saint John's Bible: Amen!
Bonjour Japon: A Parisian Love Affair with Japanese Art
exhibition_description:
Like a tidal wave hitting the shore, the impact of Japanese art on European artists of the late nineteenth century was startling and profound. Japanese woodblock prints, screens, scrolls, and decorative objects opened new aesthetic possibilities, particularly for artists working in Paris at the turn of the century. Ukiyo-e woodcuts and a wide variety of Japanese artifacts were on display at World Fairs, in commercial galleries, and in Parisian private collections. Virtually every artist working in Paris at the end of the century felt the influence of Japanese art. Western artists incorporated asymmetrical compositions, calligraphic lines, bird’s-eye views, flat areas of color, bold patterns, and outlines into their work. Inspired by the Japanese love of subjects from everyday life and nature, European artists explored similar themes, while Japanese screens, scrolls, and fans led to the appearance of similar formats in Parisian galleries and exhibitions. 
Bonjour Japon: A Parisian Love Affair with Japanese Art will capitalize on two major strengths within the MIA’s permanent collection—turn-of-the-century French prints and Japanese art. The works in this exhibition will come from the MIA’s permanent collection of prints and drawings and be organized into four thematic groupings mixing a broad scope of artists including Pierre Bonnard, Mary Cassatt, Edgar Degas, Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, and Edouard Vuillard. The categories will echo the organization of the adjacent and complementary Edo Pop: The Graphic Impact of Japanese Prints. This synergy will allow visitors to continue their journey through the museum and enable them to easily continue their exploration of the concept of ukiyo-e.

exhibition_title: Revealing the African Presence in Renaissance Europe
Craft and the Hand: From Visible to Integral
exhibition_description:
The world of the handmade object is changing. Makers, curators, collectors, and scholars are discussing the expansion of the contemporary craft field into conceptual areas. Crucial to this discussion is the current role of traditional values, such as function and perfection, as expressed through craft objects. Can these concepts be examined on a sliding scale of emphasis when applied to craft-based media?
Craft and the Hand explores these various perspectives. The exhibition takes as a point of reference the role of the hand in contemporary craft, a fundamental concept that still has relevance in this changing field. Through objects in the MIA’s permanent collection and various loans, Craft and the Hand explores, through thematic groupings, how very different philosophies are carried out by craft-based artists in their work. These range from perfection of form through skill, to using excellent handcraft to achieve a conceptual emphasis, to conscious elimination of the mark of the hand. Featured artists include Bob Stocksdale, Warren MacKenzie, Ken Price, Susan Warner, Frank E. Cummings III, and Amy Sabrina.

exhibition_title: Winterlights at the Purcell-Cutts House
Semblances: Jennifer Danos, Natasha Pestich and Marcus Young
exhibition_description: Jennifer Danos, Natasha Pestich, and Marcus Young will investigate the concept of semblance and repetition in the context of the museum. For them, semblance in art has the potential to question the idea of originality, the institution of the museum, and the act of viewership. The focus of their ambitious collaborative exhibition is to create three versions of semblance—"false" publications of posters, announcements, and newspapers to be distributed in the museum (Pestich); the re-imagining of the contemporary prints & drawings gallery (Danos); and pervasive soft singing with MIA staff (Young)—three approaches that play with and disrupt the museum site.

exhibition_title: Richard Hamilton: Pop Art Pioneer, 1922-2011
exhibition_description: Richard Hamilton was a seminal figure in Pop Art. This installation of Hamilton's well-known multiple "Five Tyres Remoulded," 1972 has not previously been on view at the MIA. The portfolio consists of seven color screen prints on Mylar, one color collotype of text and images, and one cast relief in white synthetic rubber.

exhibition_title: The Sports Show: Minnesota
exhibition_description: This exhibition features photographs of sports as part of everyday life in Minnesota from the late 19th century to the present day. It includes a wide range of images of people, places, and games that capture the spirit of Minnesota sports history. Come see a panorama of the Minnesota State Fair from the early 19th century when race car driving was in vogue; old photographs of roller derby, wrestling, and ice hockey; and pictures capturing the lively history of college and professional sports from the Gophers to the Twins, Vikings, Timberwolves, and the Wild.

exhibition_title: Painted to Printed: The Book In Transition
exhibition_description:
Prior to 1450, all European books were made by hand. Scribes copied texts letter by letter. To illustrate or decorate the pages, artists used pens and brushes to apply ink or paint, and sometimes further embellished them with burnished gold. In the last half of the 15th century, however, books changed dramatically. By the year 1500, printing presses had taken over much of the work.
Johannes Gutenberg’s invention of movable type—perfected by 1450—immediately revolutionized the replication of texts, but the transformation of illustration and decoration took longer. For decades, many books were hybrids with printed texts and hand-made decoration. Printed images—with or without coloring—slowly began to appear in books. 
Before the printing revolution, the most skilled artists illustrated only books meant for the richest and most powerful patrons. Once printed images could be issued in great numbers, however, great artists began to design illustrations for books catering to the middle class. Albrecht Dürer so fully understood the potential of printed books of pictures that he even assumed the role of publisher, taking control of the entire process, from design, to production, to distribution. His illustrations for The Apocalypse (1498) proved black-and-white images could be so compelling that one would not want to spoil them with coloring.
By looking at single leaves from books dismembered long ago, one can reconstruct the history of book illustration. Here you can see comparisons of painted and printed works, as well as objects that combine both processes. In many cases, the printed works were made to simulate their painted predecessors, but sometimes influence ran in the opposite direction. Witness the ingenuity printers brought to mass production. Some attempted to print text and image from a single surface or to employ modular elements that could be re-used and re-combined. Others tried to use finely engraved copper printing plates, although woodcuts ultimately proved more practical. While the gem-like quality

90° South: Chris Willcox
exhibition_description: Chris Willcox, who teaches painting at Macalester College in St. Paul, first became interested in the history of Antarctica after reading about the Antarctic Treaty of 1961, in which the continent was set aside as a scientific preserve. Working with the documentary photographs from early expeditions, Willcox creates painterly pastiches that capture the beautifully bleak Arctic landscape. She also makes psychological group portraits of these Heroic Age explorers.

Standards: Mark Ostapchuk
exhibition_description: Ostapchuk, an adjunct lecturer at the University of Minnesota, has been making large, abstract oil paintings for many years. He combines a frenetic color palette with controlled compositions, thin glazes with textured and burnished layers of paint. Ostapchuk calls this new suite of paintings "standards," in order to link his project as a painter to his knowledge of music, especially jazz. The paintings repeat tones and add improvisational flourishes.

exhibition_title: The Greek of Toledo
MCAD@MIA 2012: Field Inversion
Layered Abstraction: Quilting and Contemporary Fiber Art
exhibition_description:
Contemporary fiber artists working over the last forty years have mined American folk quilts for techniques and patterns commonly seen in these ubiquitous domestic objects. Drawing inspiration from the quilt’s geometric structure, contrasting, often bold color and fabric combinations, and decorative layers of stitches, the artists featured in this exhibition explore personal expression through references to this traditional textile art. Combining multiple techniques with a conscious, sophisticated approach to composition, many of these works can be seen in the context of the so-called “surface design” movement active since the 1970s. 
 “Layered Abstraction” features a variety of contemporary fiber art from the MIA’s collection. In addition to works by Sheila Hicks, Jack Lenor Larsen, and Jan Myers, it will showcase a recent MIA acquisition: Mary Lee Bendolph’s striking quilt, Strings, a contemporary example of the Gee’s Bend, Alabama quilting style. Strings well illustrates how the Gee’s Bend quilters have interpreted traditional designs in highly-individualized fashions, producing functional quilts that are now prized as abstract artworks. The exhibition will also feature quilt-inspired garments from the Goldstein Museum of Design and, as part of the MIA’s ReMix initiative, an exploration of layered abstraction in relief sculpture by Minnesota abstract artist Charles Biederman.

exhibition_title: Seven Billion: Gregory Fitz
exhibition_description: This exhibition will be the debut of Gregory Fitz’s ambitious 3-part installation. Comprised of day-glo gestural landscapes, paintings made after Ansel Adams photographs, and cinder block table sculptures, “Seven Billion” is a response to the aesthetic projects of modern art and architecture. It’s no accident that Fitz’s work is made from economical materials such as insulation foam and chip board, or that he works so quickly. By doing so he wants to leave his decision making process visible and make a counter-point to the legacy of modern painters and sculptors. This leaves his work wide open for questions about the sacred value given art, the environmental concerns of art making, and the emphasis placed on craft and presentation. Fitz’s work has been part of group exhibitions at Form+Content, the Soap Factory and Weisman Art Museum.

exhibition_title: Isohyet, Isopleth: Katelyn Farstad and David Frohlich
exhibition_description: “Isohyet, Isopleth” is the second collaborative installation by Katelyn Farstad and David Frohlich. The title of the exhibition is borrowed from meteorological terms for lines on a map that are drawn in order to connect two or more points that share similar data. For two artists who are working together on a single exhibition, they are terms that allude to what might happen when different work styles merge in the space of a single exhibition. This show will be comprised of new paintings, prints, and sculptures, in various media. And through these works, audiences will be able see how their exhibition showcases their expanded practice and how they use concepts of idle time and desperation in their work. Both Farstad and Frohlic have exhibited extensively in the Twin Cities, including the Soap Factory, Art of This, and They Won’t Find Us Here.

exhibition_title: More Real? Art in the Age of Truthiness
exhibition_description:
The past century has been a period of unprecedented technological change and global social upheaval, causing a dramatic shift in our collective perception and experience of reality. Once agreed-upon beliefs, or “truths,” have been cast into doubt. As viewers of The Colbert Report know, we are living in an age of “truthiness,” where things we wish to be true are preferred to things we know are true. 
In this exhibition, contemporary artists from around the world use unexpected and diverse means to explore this modern conundrum. Their work can be divided into three general categories (often overlapping).
1—Deception and Play: From Trompe l’Oeil to the Authentic Fake
These artworks appear to be paintings or sculptures, but play with deception, navigating the borders of illusion and reality, between the authentic and the fake.
2—Reshaping the Real: Film, Memory, and the Virtual
This art uses film, video, and photography—media once thought to faithfully reproduce reality—to challenge assumptions about the physical and the virtual.
3—The Status of Fact: Unreliable Narrators, Parafiction, and Truthiness
Such artists create fictional identities, stories, and works that are presented as fact. 
The artworks in More Real? Art in the Age of Truthiness grapple with fascinating questions about the world today: How do we define what is real in a world where a multitude of media can radically reshape the original experience being depicted? What is the role of technology in such artistic expressions? How do we navigate between truthiness and deception in everyday life? When can fiction be truthful? 
In a time when the relationship between fact and fiction has never been murkier, the artists in “More Real?” explore a shifting sense of what is real and what is not, and the consequences of not understanding the difference. 
The exhibition More Real? Art in the Age of Truthiness, along with an accompanying 304-page catalogue and an interpretive website, provides a broad historical and cultural context for the questions that

exhibition_title: Joint Ownership 2012-2014
Synthesis 3D: Artist Multiples
exhibition_description: Selected from the MIA’s permanent collection and several private Minnesota collections, the exhibition features more than 40 artist multiples (reproducible art) from the 1960s to the present by leading international modern and contemporary artists.

exhibition_title: Drawings from the Bequest of Professor Alfred Moir
exhibition_description: Art historian Alfred Moir (1924-2010) of Santa Barbara has bequeathed his superb collection of art to the Minneapolis Institute of Art. The gift, which comprises over 250 works, includes drawings, watercolors, paintings, and prints. It is particularly rich in Italian old master drawings, with rare and outstanding works by such artists as Domenico Beccafumi, Annibale and Ludovico Carracci, Salvator Rosa, Giambattista and Giandomenico Tiepolo, and Federico Zuccaro, and will enrich the MIA’s holdings in this area exponentially. Alfred Moir was born and raised in Minneapolis, but spent most of his life in southern California. A specialist in 17th-century art, he was a professor at the University of California, Santa Barbara, where he taught for almost 30 years and retired emeritus in 1991. A selection of works from his collection will be featured in this exhibition.

exhibition_title: Rembrandt's Miniature World
exhibition_description: Rembrandt's artistic output was by no means confined to painting. In fact, many consider him the greatest printmaker of all time. Concurrently with "Rembrandt in America," the MIA will present an exhibition of the master's etchings. From quick sketches to elaborate baroque masterpieces, Rembrandt produced an astonishingly imaginative and diverse body of work. He studied beggars in the street, loved ones in his home, and unforgettably his own likeness--sometimes growling at us, sometimes costumed as a dandy, sometimes displaying full awareness of his own limitations. He recorded the world around him, from humble animals to majestic trees to dilapidated farmhouses. He reimagined the stories of the Bible, each time endowing the scene with drama or tender human emotion. This exhibition shows the mind of a genius at work.

exhibition_title: Luke Aleckson "U.N.P.A.C. (Uniform Non-coding Parallax Autostereogrammic Cyclopti-cryptograms)"
Justin Quinn "Deeper Wonders Than the Waves"
exhibition_description: At the heart of Justin Quinn’s concept-driven art practice is an interest in disappearance and illegibility. His fastidious drawings, sculptures, and books are a collaboration with excerpts from classic literature but he has replaced the words with thousands of individual "Es", inserted gaps, and bent the lines to make the original text unreadable. He is exacting in how the resulting forms follow the precise word count of the original text, yet, like a concrete poem, turned them into abstract and architectural compositions of the narrative that spread the edge of the page. The silver-point mark making he uses in the large-scale graphite and ink drawings will slowly tarnish, turn to black, and no longer be visible on the hand-made paper. Also on display in “Deeper Wonders Than the Waves” are scattered floor sculptures are bent paper drawings that barely stand up as 3-dimensional forms. Finally, there is Quinn’s self-published book which is bound with hundreds of screen-copied prints of the same page.

exhibition_title: Andy Warhol and his Contemporaries: an urban milieu--New York in the 60s and 70s
Focus on a Masterpiece: Albrecht Dürer's Melencolia
Coming Out Party: Broc Blegen
exhibition_description: “Coming Out Party” will showcase new multimedia wok that includes ready-made and fabricated conceptual art pieces Broc Blegen has meticulously copied from original works of art. They are attributed to the original artists but have become part of his personal art collection; it’s his way of living with compelling artworks without the prohibitive cost of purchasing the originals. Blegen has included many familiar names in his collection, especially those artists interested in identity politics, such as Glenn Ligon, Jonathan Horowitz, and Jenny Holzer. The works in the show will provoke interesting questions about religion, gay rights, and the economics of art patronage and collecting.

exhibition_title: Remnants and Rumination: Binod Shrestha
exhibition_description: As a young art student growing up in Nepal, Binod Shrestha marched in a quest for democracy and later witnessed years of civil war between Maoist rebels and the ruling monarchy. From his new home in America, amid a global war on terror, these previous experiences continue to permeate his work. Taking frequent trips to visit family and friends in Nepal over the years, he has returned with recorded testimonies from others who have seen and suffered the violence firsthand. In Nine Steps dozens of his earthenware pots have been punctured and torn apart. Shrestha’s installations and smaller works, made of elemental materials such as mud, wood, and sand, are metaphors for the collective human bodies who have suffered from intense physical and political pressures.

exhibition_title: Pre-Raphaelites: Victorian Art and Design
Winterlights at the Purcell-Cutts House 2012
New Pictures 7: Stan Douglas: Then and Now
exhibition_description: Stan Douglas is a photographer, filmmaker, and installation artist, whose works have been exhibited internationally, including in three Venice biennales and three dOCUMENTAs. After conducting intensive research, he restages historical events using actors, costumes, props, and sets. Douglas was awarded the prestigious Infinity Award for Art by the International Center for Photography in 2012.

exhibition_title: A Handsome Cupboard of Plate: Early American Silver in the Cahn Collection
exhibition_description:
The cupboard of early American domestic and presentation silver assembled by Paul and Elissa Cahn over some thirty years is unified by strong design, fine craftsmanship, and awareness on the part of the collectors for both the course of American history and the history of the craft in the colonies.
“A Handsome Cupboard of Plate” begins in Boston, with a c. 1690 caudle cup marked by the first native-born American silversmith—Jeremiah Dummer (1645-1718)—which has a history of ownership in the Tufts family of Massachusetts—proceeds to New York, with a robust tankard and a distinctive large fluted and gadrooned caster reflecting the Dutch heritage of that region marked by Bartholomew Schaats (1683-1758), and progresses to Philadelphia, where generations of the Quaker Richardson family supplied goods of the “best sort, but plain” to their clientele, including Lydia and Oswald Peel, who acquired an octagonal covered sugar dish and tea caddies ca. 1736.
Silver of the post-Revolutionary War era in the Cahn cupboard documents transitions to a new aesthetic that exploited available technology for rolling sheet metal and a neoclassical ornamental vocabulary. The shop of patriot Paul Revere Jr. notably utilized both new manufacturing techniques and the new ornament. These changes are apparent in the laurel-leaf wreath enclosing the dedicatory inscription on the Danielson Family commemorative tankard (c. 1783), and in the seamed, fluted, and swag-and-tassel engraved Adams-Quincy teapot with stand (c. 1790). In New York and Philadelphia, the shops of Myer Myers and Joseph Lownes (1758-1820) utilized the sleek, smooth, “flatted” (rolled) sheet silver in hooped tankards and canns, respectively.
The end of the second presidential term of George Washington in 1797 closes out the Cahn cupboard of plate. Myer Myers died in 1795; Joseph Richardson II became second assayer at the U. S. Mint (by Washington’s appointment), and Paul Revere Jr. left the artisan silversmith’s shop to preside over industrial production of bells, cannon,

venues.venue: DeWitt Wallace Decorative Arts Museum, The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation

exhibition_title: Picturing Poverty: Artistic Views of the Poor in the Baroque Era
exhibition_description:
During the 17th century, artists in Europe began looking to everyday life for their subjects, with special attention to the poor.
The plight of the impoverished came to the fore during the Thirty Years War (1618–48), which reduced broad swaths of Europe to subsistence living or starvation. People were also familiar with Gospel teachings that exalted the poor as inheritors of the kingdom of heaven. Jesus himself was born in a humble stable and had simple shepherds as his first visitors. Artist after artist depicted the Holy Family’s flight into Egypt, riding on a donkey and cooking over a campfire. A strong note of compassion informed the work of Stefano della Bella and Rembrandt, whose portrayals of wretched humanity in this exhibition often took on a remarkably personal character.
Many artists were able to find a sort of ragged dignity in the lower levels of society. They showed the poor in attitudes of industrious acceptance or stoicism, where a battered hat became a crown of virtue, a sign of resolute endurance of a miserable life. Such fortitude found adherents especially in France with the Le Nain brothers, whose sympathies are evident in the realism of their painting now in the Louvre, where poor farmers are portrayed, in all their deprivation and sad acceptance of poverty.
In other cases, an insistent attention to the decorative value of tattered and patched clothes—torn caps and shoes, wrinkles, sagging cheeks—suggests a colder curiosity, a simple pleasure in the representation of the picturesque, and a willingness to caricature misery.
As this exhibition demonstrates, artists interpreted poverty in many ways. For Adriaen van Ostade, it sometimes became the equivalent (both in cause and consequence) of spiritual misery. For William Hogarth, it would lead to the social denunciation described in his famous satire Gin Lane (1751). Whether the emphasis was on debauchery or the delineation of a frayed hem, the work of Baroque-era artists found the poor to be rich subject matter indeed.

exhibition_department: Art of Africa and the Americas
exhibition_title: Visions from the Forests: The Art of Liberia and Sierra Leone
exhibition_description:
Visions from the Forests: The Art of Liberia and Sierra Leone is the collection brought together between 1965 and 1987 by the late William Siegmann. Siegmann visited Liberia for the first time in 1965 to teach history. In the ensuing decades he lived on and off in Liberia for fifteen years, pursued a graduate degree in African art history at Indiana University, and was a major force behind the development of two museums in Liberia. During this time he developed a life-long passion – and formidable eye – for African art resulting in an extensive personal collection. In 1987 he became the Curator of African Art at the Brooklyn Museum of Art and continued research on his collection. Before he passed away in November 2011, Siegmann – a native of Minneapolis who had maintained strong connections with his hometown – started donating portions of his collection to various museums including the Minneapolis Institute of Arts.
Covering a period from the fifteenth to the late twentieth centuries, with many examples from the nineteenth century, Visions from the Forests: The Art of Liberia and Sierra Leone will showcase approximately seventy-five pieces, created by artists from over a dozen different ethnic groups. Some of the highlights include: a Mano face mask with feathers and shoulder cap; a large horizontal mask from the Loma; a Vai helmet mask by an identified yet unnamed master carver from around 1900; a rare wooden female figure by a Sherbro artist; a brass tortoise cast by the famous Dan caster Ldamie of Gaple; a unique sixteenth century Sapi stone sculpture representing a seated couple; ceremonial horn pendants adorned with silver in which inscriptions in Arabic and Vai have been written; a late eighteenth century side-blown ivory horn from the Krim; a Temne chiefly hat in silver modeled after a fez; and a tie dyed wrapper designed by contemporary artist Christina Tombe.

exhibition_title: Supper with Shakespeare: The Evolution of English Banqueting
exhibition_description:
In collaboration with world-renowned English culinary historian Ivan Day, the Minneapolis Institute of Arts will present the exhibition, Supper with Shakespeare: The Evolution of English Banqueting, December 13, 2012 – March 31, 2013. The term “banquet” in the context of sixteenth and seventeenth century England meant a visually striking collection of after dinner sweet foods, preserves, and confections. In Shakespeare’s time (he died in 1616), such displays of culinary wonder were among the most magnificent in the history of British dining. Banquets were intended to impress and delight diners while the servants cleared the remains of the main feast, so they were often held in outdoor “banqueting houses” or in an intimate chamber such as the MIA’s Tudor Room. 
In 1923, the Minneapolis Institute of Arts installed the Tudor Room as the museum's first period room, calling it "the very embodiment of the spirit of the seventeenth century." Furnished with a rich assortment of tables, chairs, and case furniture that evoke the furnishings and lifestyle of Tudor England, the room’s oak paneling dates to about 1600. Once part of a private chamber used for eating, sitting, and entertaining guests, the room came to the MIA with a history of use in a manor in Suffolk, England. 
For Supper with Shakespeare, the Tudor Room will be laid out with a full banquet of period culinary delights hand-crafted by Ivan Day. The exhibition will continue in the adjacent Briggs Court, featuring dining related objects of silver, ceramic, and glass from the MIA’s collection, as well as an assortment of loan objects such as period cookbooks, food moulds, and kitchen utensils. The whole will enchant art lovers and foodies alike! 
Planned programs include a “Supper with Shakespeare” public lecture by guest curator Ivan Day on Thursday, December 13, 2012 at 11:00 am, sponsored by the Friends of the MIA; a private Tudor-inspired feast curated by Ivan Day, date TBD, complete with a special Tudor inspired ale locally brewed for the occasion; and

exhibition_title: Edo Pop: The Graphic Impact of Japanese Prints (JS)
The House We Built: Feminist Art Then and Now
China's Terracotta Warriors: The First Emperor's Legacy
The World at Work: Images of Labor and Industry, 1850 to Now
exhibition_description:
For centuries, artists have explored the world of work and workers, creating enduring impressions of the challenges, triumphs, and life-affirming dignity of human labor. From romanticized visions of agrarian life, to sobering depictions of beleaguered manual laborers and miners, to scenes of worksites, factories, and industrial landscapes, these images reveal strikingly diverse interpretations of what it means to work. The subject is especially prevalent among graphic artists and photographers, who have exploited the power of reproduction to disseminate their ideas.

Selected entirely from the MIA’s permanent collection, the exhibition showcases more than fifty original prints, drawings, and photographs by prominent American and international artists and photographers active from the mid-nineteenth century to the present. The selection will include important examples by Jean-François Millet, Auguste Lepere, Edgar Degas, Pierre Bonnard, James McNeill Whistler, Muirhead Bone, Käthe Kollwitz, Rockwell Kent, Romare Bearden, Lewis Hine, Joseph Pennell, Louis Lozowick, Joseph Stella, Charles Sheeler, Harry Sternberg, Grant Wood, John Steuart Curry, Elizabeth Catlett, W. Eugene Smith, David Parker, James Rosenquist, Jim Dine, Donald Sultan, Herb Ritts, Sebastião Salgado, and others.
